business.start.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Paul Calvert) took the chair at 12.30 pm and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —I present letters from the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, and the Leader of The Nationals in the Senate, Senator Boswell, requesting me to summon the Senate to meet today to consider the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005.
—I seek leave to take note of those letters.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris (Manager of Government Business in the Senate)
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate
talker.name: Senator ELLISON

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to move a motion relating to the hours of meeting and routine of business for today.

speech.para: Leave not granted.

talker.name: Ellison, Sen Chris (Manager of Government Business in the Senate)
talker.role: Manager of Government Business in the Senate
talker.name: Senator ELLISON

talk.start.para: —Pursuant to contingent notice standing in the name of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill, I move:

motion.para: That so much of standing orders be suspended as would prevent me moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion to vary the hours of meeting and routine of business for today.

talk.start.para: —The substantive motion seeks to rearrange the business, but the important preceding factor is the recall of the Senate to deal with that business, which I sought to talk about a moment ago. It is an outrageous abuse of this parliament for the Prime Minister to recall the Senate today to deal with legislation which could have been dealt with on any of the last 200 days, any time in the last 18 months, in the ordinary sittings of the Senate.

speech.para: The problem is that the Prime Minister needed to concoct a situation to divert attention from the industrial relations legislation—those draconian measures which entered the House of Representatives yesterday when the Senate was not sitting. He needed to be able to divert attention away from the terror in the workplace that will come out of that legislation, which will be the sheer inability of people to stand up—after 100 years of protection for workers with the unions—in the workplace as their wages and conditions are eroded by this legislation which cuts right across a century of ‘fair go’ in Australia. The Prime Minister knows that the legislation is hugely unpopular. The Prime Minister knows that Australians hate this robbery of the rights of workers to be adequately defended in the workplace, but the Prime Minister is determined to put it through.

The Prime Minister also knows that people are concerned about terrorism. So what does he do? He abuses that fear by dropping, yesterday—not the day before, not the day after—this supposed new threat against public order and safety in Australia. It is such a threat that the government is not prepared to talk with members of parliament about it. The government refused me, as Leader of the Australian Greens, a briefing about it. The government has not told other government members about it. Nevertheless it wants to have us all believe that something different has occurred, even though the ASIO report says that Australia has been of interest to terrorists every day of every year for the last six years. What is new here?

It is not sufficient to have the Attorney-General too worried. He says that the measures that we have been brought back for today are important, but there is no guarantee that particular action will be taken. It is feasible something might happen. You tell me which day of the last 18 months it has not been feasible that some action might be taken by criminal elements here or elsewhere against Australian interests. This is a manipulation by the Prime Minister of this country against proper process. It is a slight on this parliament; it is a farce. Are we to stand here and simply say, ‘Put it through to the keeper’? We must not say anything against any law in these circumstances.

We might look at the words of much-greater Prime Minister Curtin, who warned 30 or 40 years ago that those of us who concede—for a moment, a political passing—great and important freedoms and liberties in our democracy are doing the wrong thing. The Greens will not do that. We will not be part of this situation where the Prime Minister is manipulating this parliament and the people of Australia to gain political advantage.

talker.name: Hill, Robert (Leader of the Government in the Senate)
talker.role: Leader of the Government in the Senate
talker.name: Senator HILL

talk.start.para: —I would like to thank honourable senators for their willingness to answer the call. I know that it has been a significant inconvenience to some who are in far distant places in our large continent, but the willingness of honourable senators to jump on the next plane and return because of the advice that they received that the Senate was being recalled is something that I would like to recognise and that I appreciate. I rang leaders of other parties and Independents yesterday to advise them of this decision; I was treated courteously and cooperatively, and I appreciated that as well.

speech.para: I am sorry that Senator Bob Brown seeks to debase this process in the way that he has. It is insulting and offensive, not only to honourable senators but perhaps more importantly to the intelligence agencies and law enforcement agencies that have in effect initiated this process. When the Prime Minister receives information that requires a course of action to be taken in the best interests of protecting Australians and decides to act upon that, I think that most reasonable men and women would accept that in good faith, rather than try to attribute some short-term base political objective to it. But Senator Brown, of course, has never been prepared to do that. No matter how important or critical the issue, Senator Brown will seek to use it for his short-term political objectives, and the way that he has done that in this instance, I think, is disappointing and a reflection upon him and his party. But, anyway, that is his business.

We are anxious that the legislation be passed today, for the reasons that have been made public. In relation to other important issues, including the broader debate on the major anti-terrorism package, I am pleased that we will now be able to facilitate a longer debate than I thought would be possible in the Senate, and we are looking to—

talk.start.para: —Yes, we noticed you’ve been a real champion of the Senate committee process recently!

—On the one hand, I am disappointed that the state premiers have delayed the introduction of that bill into the House of Representatives but, on the other hand, it does mean that the Senate committee system will have longer to look at the matter and of course I welcome that. In relation to the industrial relations package, the Senate committee will also be busy during the up fortnight looking at the detail of that important legislation as well. And I hope that we will be able to pass the relevant resolutions with regard to those matters as well today. I thank the honourable senators, with the exception of the Greens, for their support in the return of the Senate and being prepared to constructively deal with the legislation before us today.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —Can I indicate on behalf of the Labor opposition that we will be supporting the government’s procedural motions that facilitate dealing with the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005 today. I think it is now called the anti-terrorism bill (No. 1) and is what we in the Labor Party refer to as the mini-package rather than the maxi-package. I do want to put it on the record that Senator Hill did consult with us about the recall of the Senate and that Labor supported that recall. We have made Labor senators available on the basis of the advice regarding the need for this legislation. I will go to that when we debate the bill, more importantly, but I do want to indicate to the minor parties and other senators that Labor will be supporting the government in all procedural resolutions proposed today which facilitate the debate on this bill, and we will be supporting the passage of the bill. I am happy to debate that and make a contribution myself when we get to that, but I think we ought to do that.

speech.para: I did put it to Senator Hill that there were two things we wanted to have addressed as part of that process. One was to ensure that the estimates committees could go ahead and do their important work, and that has been agreed and I appreciate that. The second thing that we have been concerned about is that we have a proper inquiry into the maxi-bill, the major anti-terrorism legislation, because we share the concerns of many in the community that there be proper scrutiny of that legislation. We have had some public debate in the last few weeks about the provisions, but we have yet to see the exact provisions. I think it is important that the Senate be allowed to do its job in examining the legislation through a Senate inquiry and to do its job in having a proper parliamentary debate on and scrutiny of the legislation.

While the minister is today pleased to announce that the government will be supporting an inquiry, I note that he was not pleased to support it a couple of weeks ago. But the government has been forced into that position by the public outcry and the pressure from the media, the premiers and other parties that the government pay proper respect to parliamentary process, not abuse its Senate majority. While Senator Hill might want to put a good face on it today, I regard it as a humiliating backdown and a sign to the government that in fact a Senate majority does not mean total power in our political processes, that the involvement of the community and public debate is also important and the government will have to respond to that. It will have to respond to that on the IR legislation and on the terrorism legislation, because people are interested; they are concerned. If the government is going to continue to abuse Senate process then I think it will pay a heavy price.

Labor will be supporting the procedural motions that allow us to debate the bill—that will allow all senators to express their views on the bill. I think it is a sensible way forward and we have supported the recall of parliament. I was pleased to see that, I think, 25 of the 28 Labor senators were already in town, which was very pleasing because it shows their commitment to holding the government accountable during the estimates process. It was a more impressive number than I thought we would have, so I congratulate my colleagues on being here. We did not have to fly people back. I think we had two overseas and one sick, so I suspect the government was more hard-pressed in terms of its numbers. Nevertheless, we will not be supporting anything that prevents the chamber from dealing with and allowing proper debate on the bill today. I think it is important we move on, having guaranteed both a proper inquiry process for the major terrorism legislation and the continuation of the estimates committee process. As I say, I think more substantial debate ought to occur when we get to the bill.

talk.start.para: —I was going to wait until the substantive motion was moved to make some comments, but given that some of those issues have been raised, it is appropriate to speak now. I will not address the content of the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005; we will have the opportunity to do that later. Given that the government senators—and, I should note, solely the government senators—decided to recall the Senate today and we are here, we may as well debate it. I put on the record that the Democrats were notified that the decision had been made to recall the Senate; we were not consulted as to whether we thought it was a good idea. Indeed, we were notified, as I understand it, before the amendments that we are debating today were even made public.

speech.para: We are dealing with two issues here today. One is whether or not the legislation should be supported, and we will get to that when the legislation is before us. The other is the circumstances surrounding what is quite an unusual circumstance, in the Senate being recalled to sit, with almost 24 hours notice—I think it was at about this time yesterday that we were notified that it would be recalled the next day—specifically to pass something in the context of public statements that have generated an enormous amount of publicity, suggesting that Australia is now under much more serious, direct and immediate threat of some form of unspecified attack from terrorists.

There are a couple of points that need to be made in that regard. Firstly, the government have said, and the Minister for Defence has just repeated, that they will now agree to what the Democrats put forward, and the amendment that I moved when we last sat, that there be at least three weeks for a Senate committee to examine the full legislation. It is a clear backdown on the part of the government for them to now agree to that. Senator Hill is saying it is because the state governments took longer than they should have. The fact is that the legislation, as I understand it, is going to be introduced into the Senate today. Even if the state premiers had acquiesced as instantly as possible, the very earliest it would have been tabled was on Monday. The minister knows, and all government members know, that because estimates committees are meeting now, this would not have permitted any significant amount of extra scrutiny than we would have got anyway. So to suggest that because the Labor premiers have taken a bit longer is the reason why the government are now going to agree to an extra three weeks is a furphy.

The simple fact is that Senator Hill came in here without notice late on the last sitting day and said, ‘We have to have this inquiry done within the space of a week, reporting back on 8 November. There is no alternative.’ When I got up and moved an amendment to provide scope for some degree of scrutiny, all we got was the usual smears from government senators saying that we are soft on terrorism and we are more concerned about Senate process than we are about the safety of Australians. Now what do we have? We have Senator Hill saying, ‘It’s okay. A few extra weeks—that’s good.’ It is the typical thing you get from this government: total perversion of process, and then anyone who even raises a query gets slandered as being anti-Australian, soft on terrorism and putting Australians’ lives at risk for their own political interests.

I think there is a clear suspicion on the part of many Australians that it is the Prime Minister who is advancing his own political interests here by creating a false sense of urgency. When we look at the substance of this legislation, we need to see why such a minor change is so urgent. Are we going to see arrests over the weekend? Clearly, what is in this legislation is in no way necessary to prevent police or security officials acting right now if they believe somebody is planning to conduct any sort of act of violence against Australians over the next few days. All it may do is perhaps make it slightly easier for them to secure a successful conviction on the grounds of terrorism as opposed to on the grounds of any other type of violence.

The government, by doing this in this way and creating publicity and a big fuss, did not just distract from the IR outrage. It also signalled to any potential terrorists out there that maybe somebody is on to them. Whether or not that is in Australia’s public interest, I do not know. But given this government’s history of misusing the intelligence agencies, politicising the defence forces, public servants and intelligence agencies, and having scant regard for the existing laws, you cannot blame Australians for being very suspicious that it is doing the same thing again—putting its own political interests ahead of due process. We are here now; we may as well debate the legislation. But let us not suggest that somehow or other this legislation is a major change that is absolutely essential to protect Australians over the weekend. (Time expired)

talker.name: Fielding, Sen Steve
talker.role: Leader of the Family First Party
talker.name: Senator FIELDING

talk.start.para: —I support the rearrangement of business today to look at the urgent issue of change to the existing legislation. I make it clear that Family First has not been briefed on the specific details of the urgency of the issue. But I support the fact that the rearrangement of business is needed and I have taken the government at their word that it is urgent. We want to make sure that families are safe and secure in this nation.

speech.para: I also want to ensure that the chairs of the various estimates committees pay particular attention to the fact that people may need to be in the chamber at a time when they need to ask questions and therefore may need to be given a bit of leniency having regard to some of the timings of those estimates committees. It is very important that estimates committees are treated with seriousness and not with contempt. Obviously this is an urgent matter and I have taken the government at their word, so we do support this rearrangement of business.

talk.start.para: —We all agree that it is a very serious matter to recall the Senate and that, when the government does so, it is required to give a justification and reason for it. The Prime Minister would say that he thinks he has done that. He has not done that for the Greens. He has not provided us with a rationale and a reason why we are all back here today—and he has not done that for the Australian public. The Prime Minister is saying, ‘Trust me.’ This Prime Minister does not have a very good track record in standing up and saying to the Australian public, ‘Trust me.’ I can talk about children overboard and weapons of mass destruction. I can talk about a whole lot of issues on which this Prime Minister’s track record in saying, ‘Trust me,’ just does not stand up. That is what the Prime Minister is saying to us today. He is saying, ‘Trust me. Let’s spend this taxpayers’ money getting everyone back here, and we’re going to make changes to the law which mean that we will be able to arrest people.’

speech.para: Let us have a look at what we have already got in our criminal law. In our criminal law, the government has the capacity—thanks to legislation passed by both of the major parties in the Senate over 18 months ago—to arrest people if it suspects that it has information about a terrorist attack. The government already has the power to arrest people if it believes that they are talking about or are engaged in activities, planning or preparation for a non-specific terrorist act. Not only does the government have that power right now—today, before we debate this legislation—but it is also acting on that power. There is a court case going on at the moment involving Jack Thomas in Victoria. He has been taken to court because the government believes that he was sitting around talking with a group of other people about how he might or they might engage in a non-specific terrorist act. That is the evidence this government has taken before the court under existing law in order to take this man to trial right now in Victoria.

So when the Prime Minister says to us, ‘We all need to come back here and pass this legislation so that we can arrest a group of people who might be talking with others about a potential, non-specific terrorist act,’ I say: ‘What do you already have the power to do? What are you already doing for exactly this point?’ That is your case. That is the Commonwealth’s case right now. Only two bits of evidence have been provided against Jack Thomas. One is that he sat around with some mates talking about how they might be involved in a non-specific terrorist act. The other evidence that has been put in that case is that perhaps he got some funds from al-Qaeda. You have the power to act on that one—and you are in this case and you are in others.

So when the Prime Minister stands up and says, ‘Trust me. I need you to come in here and I need you to pass this legislation because my security forces don’t have the power right now to do that,’ I say, ‘Rubbish! Absolute rubbish!’ Go and get a copy of the Criminal Code, read the thing, see what is in there and look at all the cases that you have already taken on these issues and all the people you have dragged through the court because you claimed they might have had a conversation about a non-specific terrorist act. Don’t stand up there and say to me, ‘We need you to come in here to pass this legislation,’ when you have already got that power and you are already using that power.

I am pretty cynical about this Prime Minister already, but if I look at the evidence—not my cynicism—of what this Prime Minister and this government are doing, there is no justification that I can see for why we should all be back here giving more powers to the security agencies. I have been in this parliament for over three years and I have been recalled three times out of session to sit in the Senate: once to pass terrorism legislation, again to pass terrorism legislation today, and to come here and listen to George W Bush. It does not make me really proud to say, ‘My Prime Minister and my government reckon that I should be giving the Prime Minister’s security agencies more power to lock more people away’—a power that they already have. That is what we are being called back here to do today.

This is the third time that we have been called back here. The last time was in November 2003. The only other time was so that we could listen to George W Bush and the leader of the largest communist party on this globe. That is why the Prime Minister has called us back here—they are the occasions. What he wants today is more power—power that he already has. The security agencies have the power to go out there, and that is what they should do. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —A moment ago, Senator Hill talked about debasing process. I think the fact that the Senate has been recalled with no evidence of what is going on being given to the Greens and at least these four senators who have spoken is an absolute debasement of process on the government’s part. The fact is that we were elected to represent people in various states of Australia. We were expected by those people to come here and be able to scrutinise legislation. Instead of that, we have a government with absolute power, that has had private meetings with and given private briefings to the Labor Party—and the Labor Party now say that they are satisfied that they can come in here and vote on something. I do not know how many members of the Labor Party know about this. Some of them do and some do not. Two perhaps do and the rest are taking it on trust.

speech.para: Everything here is about taking things on trust. I am being asked as a legislator to come here and rubber-stamp something I know absolutely nothing about because I am not trusted to know about it. Only a couple of people are trusted to know about it. It seems that Paul Lennon, the Premier of Tasmania, is trusted to know about the threat that is going on in this country, but the people elected to come here to this Senate are not trusted to know.

My issue is this: firstly, when did the government know about this new security threat to Australia? Clearly, it knew before the Melbourne Cup. Why didn’t the Prime Minister have his press conference on the day of the Melbourne Cup? For political reasons, I would suggest—because he did not want to disrupt the nation’s day out on Melbourne Cup day. Instead, he waited until the day that the industrial relations legislation was introduced. If this matter was so urgent—if there was a big threat to the country that had to be fixed immediately—any delay was an absolute act of irresponsibility. So it is not so urgent that it could disrupt the Melbourne Cup but it is so urgent that it can disrupt the whole nation’s focus on the industrial relations legislation.

Secondly, if it is such a big threat to the country, why hasn’t the terror alert level been raised? The nation has been told that, imminently, somewhere in the country, people are planning a terrorist attack, probably in one of the major cities—where, incidentally, the Melbourne Cup was run and where a lot of people happened to be on Tuesday. Now we discover that it is not so serious that we have to raise the terror alert level or to disrupt the nation’s day out on Melbourne Cup day but it is so serious that we have to recall the Senate and get the front-page headlines to distract from the industrial relations legislation the day after.

Again, it is about trust. I do not trust the Prime Minister. He abused the nation’s trust when we went to war in Iraq, and he elevated Australia as a terrorism target the minute he went into the coalition of the willing and the minute he went into Iraq—and everybody says so, including the terrorists. So let us not have any pretence that the heightening of the risk to this country is not fairly and squarely the responsibility of the government.

They have already done that with the issue of weapons of mass destruction; they have already tried to suggest that we went into Iraq because we were trying to bring them democracy. China could do with a bit of democracy. Mr Mugabe could do with a bit of democracy. So let us have a bit of an assessment as to what is going on here. As my colleague Senator Nettle said a moment ago, we are now doing nothing more than dancing to the tune of the Americans. Whenever we enter into any international agreements, civil rights lawyers from all over the world are now warning that to take away civil liberties in the name of fighting terrorism is an abuse of international law—and it is.

Nothing has been put to my colleagues in the Greens to show that these powers, which the government says are so urgently required, do not already exist. We have had legal advice to that effect, and I will be very keen to see the government’s legal advice to the contrary. My view is this: as an elected member of this Senate, why should I be prevented from knowing something some members are allowed to know and others are not? Is it because I might not make the same assessment of whatever it is that we are not allowed to be told? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I join my colleagues in being extremely cynical about the timing of this amendment. The government has known for a long time that this amendment was needed. The Prime Minister knew for days about a possible threat and yet he waited until after the IR legislation was introduced—legislation that is going to have a devastating impact on the workers of this country; legislation that is so thick it will take weeks to read and trawl through; legislation that will make more fundamental changes than we realised and than we were given indication of. The IR legislation will mean that anybody can be sacked at virtually any time for no reason. It takes away the no disadvantage test. It threatens the safety of workers by undermining the way we debate and look after safety. It gives the minister unprecedented powers. It demolishes our award system. I could go on and on about how it is going to change the way our workers are treated in this country. Instead of that being in the headlines in the media that night and in our newspapers today, what are in the headlines? A threat—more talk about terrorism. If anything is guaranteed to get you media attention besides the IR legislation, it is another terrorism threat.

speech.para: If the threat was so important, why weren’t these amendments brought in straightaway? Why didn’t we disrupt the Melbourne Cup? Because bringing it in and upsetting Melbourne Cup day would have upset the punters, wouldn’t it? Why weren’t these brought in earlier? Why did we have to wait until yesterday? It was so you could disguise the IR changes. And a nuclear waste dump bill went through the House of Representatives yesterday. That did not get any media attention, did it? Do you know why? Because the front pages were all about terror. This is a cynical move by the Prime Minister to divert attention from the other changes that are going to be brought in that will adversely impact on the workers of this country and adversely impact on the people of the Northern Territory.

talk.start.para: —Order! The time for the debate has expired. The question is that Senator Ellison’s motion to suspend standing orders be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Senator ELLISON
motionnospeech.role: —Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

motion.para: That a motion to vary the hours of meeting and routine of business for today may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.
That the question be now put.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the question now be put.
—The question now is that Senator Ellison’s motion be agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Senator ELLISON
motionnospeech.role: —Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

item.label: (a)
item.para: the hours of meeting for today shall be 12.30 pm to adjournment;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the routine of business shall be:

item.label: (i)
item.para: consideration of a message from the House of Representatives relating to the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005, and

item.label: (ii)
item.para: deferred votes on a motion for the reference of a bill to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee,

item.label: (c)
item.para: legislation committees considering estimates may meet during the sitting of the Senate today;

item.label: (d)
item.para: divisions may take place after 4.30 pm; and

item.label: (e)
item.para: immediately after the completion of business listed in paragraph (b), the Senate shall adjourn without any question being put.

talk.start.para: —The obvious question to ask here is: if this terrorist situation confronting Australia is so great that the Senate was required to be recalled for these hours to debate the matter then what about the proposal by the government that, nevertheless, committees should sit contemporary with this debate and that the majority of senators be elsewhere while this debate is taking place? That is not logical. We are not going to oppose that, but that is the absurd ‘illogic’ of this farcical situation. According to the Prime Minister, the nation faces a terror situation—which is unspecified and secret and which the government will not tell us about. The Senate gets recalled without consultation with the other parties. But the Prime Minister says, ‘Go ahead and have all the Senate inquiries going at the same time, because we are going to just tick it through the Senate.’ Let me tell you, that is a debasement of this chamber; that is a slight on this Senate. That is not what this Senate was meant to do.

speech.para: The business of the committees is crucial, and must be done. But if this situation is so important that we must be here as a chamber debating it, let us be here as a chamber debating it. It is absurd to say: ‘Oh, no; let the committees keep going. It doesn’t matter so far as that’s concerned. It’s not important enough to stop the committees doing their work.’ Yet it is important enough to have the Senate sit here, and we are going to have a skeleton Senate while the debate takes place. It is absurd. It makes even further nonsense of the urgency of this business. We could have debated this matter any time in the last 18 months, or we could debate it next week, but we should not be debating it today while the committees are meeting. That is part of the farce.

talk.start.para: —How many people are normally in here when you speak?

—Senator Abetz has suddenly appeared. He has been absent while this critical matter is taking place. He has been absent, but he suddenly appears to interject. One of the Prime Minster’s handservants suddenly appears in the chamber to create a bit of disruption. I welcome him, because if there is one thing I like it is a few interjections from the incapable, nonsensical and irrelevant Senator Abetz. There you are: it is an absurdity compounded by other absurdities. If it is so serious that the Prime Minister had to recall us, we ought to be debating this matter seriously. But that is not the case.

—I realise that the estimates committees cannot sit before this motion is passed, as I understand it, so I am not going to delay starting debate on the full bill any longer than I need to. But I do think a few other points need to be made with regard to the process that we are following here before we get to the substance of the legislation. There are several aspects to the minister’s motion: firstly, that we go to the legislation and debate that straightaway; secondly, that estimates committees meet whilst that debate is happening—there are four separate committees all conducting their business at the same time and therefore, of course, many senators will be occupied in those committees—and, thirdly, that we have, following that, the vote on my amendment to have a major piece of antiterrorism legislation referred to a committee for at least an extra three weeks beyond what the government was otherwise prepared to do.

speech.para: As I said before, I welcome the fact that the government has now backed down and allowed those extra three weeks for at least some semblance of a credible inquiry into the detail of the legislation. I do hope that there are at least a small number of coalition senators who have sufficient conscience still operational that they will actually take on board the evidence provided to that inquiry and consider whether or not the legislation can be improved. I would hope also that there are some members of the Labor opposition who will genuinely listen to the information provided to that Senate inquiry.

Let us remember that this legislation, whilst it has been discussed backwards and forwards between the state Labor premiers and the Liberal Prime Minister for the last few weeks, has actually been hidden from the Australian people. When Chief Minister Stanhope had the temerity to actually let the Australian people have some idea of what the various governments around the country might be considering in terms of giving themselves extra powers and taking away people’s freedoms, he was roundly pilloried by the federal government. How dare he let people know what might be done to our democracy, our Constitution and due legal process!

This is going to be the first real opportunity—and the only opportunity—that the Australian community, including many people with a lot of expertise, will have to provide input into the final legislative package which, let me remind the Senate, we still, as far as I know, have not seen. It has still not been made public, unless it has been tabled in the House of Representatives in the last few minutes. As I understand it, it will be tabled sometime today.

Let us not forget that, when I moved an amendment on the last day that we sat to enable at least a few weeks of committee inquiry, we were attacked by government members—people like Senator Ronaldson, who said that we had a choice between Senate process and the passage of this legislation. He was on the side of the passage of the legislation. How dare people like the Democrats try to insist that there be some degree of scrutiny of this! He said that, by moving to extend the Senate’s committee procedure, we were putting the public interest at risk. That is what government senators accused the Democrats of doing in trying to move an amendment to at least allow three weeks of scrutiny, which is still inadequate in my view. All of us here on this side, by indicating we wanted that to happen, were putting the public interest at risk, supposedly, by seeking to have any sort of credible inquiry at all.

I am pleased to see, as I said, that the government has now acquiesced and recognised that a few weeks of inquiry will not put the public interest at risk. It will actually serve the public interest by at least slightly increasing the chances that we will not have dramatic flaws in this legislation, however unnecessary it is. It is another example of the sorts of slurs you get from the government any time anyone wants to raise any concerns even just about the process, let alone the content.

There is one other point I would like to make in the context of this debate because I do think it is important. The detail of the legislation is important but the context in which it is put forward is also important. As I have stated—and as others have stated it—I am far from convinced that it is necessary for us to be here today to pass this legislation. If it is actually genuine that there has been a serious increase in the terrorist threat over the last day or so, I am not so sure that flagging it quite so publicly that the government is onto people is necessarily a wise thing to do, particularly when we look at the detail of the legislation, how minor a difference it makes and how completely inconsequential it is to the current abilities of the security forces and the police.

I also think it is important to emphasise that, when the Prime Minister was making his statement about why this antiterrorism legislation was so important, he gave two reasons. Firstly, he stated the need to rush this through because of the massive change involved in changing ‘the terrorist act’ to ‘a terrorist act’. Secondly, he also said in his statement that it would add a further ground for listing terrorist organisations in regulations and that was why it was urgent. I would like the minister to actually indicate where that is in the legislation, given that that was put forward as a justification for us to be rushed back here today to pass this at the same time as four separate estimates committees are meeting. Where is it in the bill that, as the Prime Minister said, this adds a further ground for listing terrorist organisations in regulations? I cannot see it. That in itself suggests to me that either the Prime Minister did not know what he was doing or he is misleading the Australian people yet again.

The final comment I would like to make in this debate is that I am extremely concerned that the context in which it is being conducted is leading once again to more and more vilification of and focus on the Australian Muslim community. That is not only unacceptable and unfair to those people but also, I believe, completely counterproductive. If we are serious about trying to reduce the terrorism threat, the last thing we want to do is alienate and target a whole specific section of the community.

Sure, there are a small number of Muslim extremists out there; there are a small number of other extremists—white supremacists who threaten violence, fathers’ rights extremists who threaten violence, anti-abortionists who threaten violence. We have always had a small number of extremists who threaten violence. But to specifically target Muslims in such an up-front way, I believe, is grossly unfair and also counterproductive.

I am very concerned about, particularly, the Australian newspaper this morning, which cooperated very conveniently with the agenda of the Prime Minister by pushing the IR debate right to one side. It put a stereotypical picture of a Muslim cleric on the front page, with the full beard and the pointed finger, and once again reinforced all those stereotypes. It said that the Prime Minister has been forced to rush this through to make it easier for police to arrest suspects, which is simply not the case, and then once again drew the target back to Muslims, front and centre, and associated it totally with Muslims. It seems that, whenever the Prime Minister finds himself in times of trouble, it is Mother Murdoch who comes to him, but I think that, sadly, they are not words of wisdom; they are words of inflammation. It is not helping the Australian community and I believe it is actually counterproductive to seriously tackling the sorts of things that lead to extremism and politically motivated violence.

It is important to make those points in the context of the debate that we are having. We will debate the legislation, which is relatively minor, shortly. But, for such a relatively minor piece of legislation, the way it has been done, quite deliberately, has created an enormous amount of extra unnecessary fear and inflamed that fear towards a particular group in the community in an unfair way. I believe we need to do much more, and the government must do much more, to condemn this sort of deliberate focusing on Muslims and specifically dissociate ourselves from that sort of targeting of one group in the community—a group in the community that we need to rely on as much as every other group in the community to single out the small number of potentially violent extremists.

We are going to need them, more than anybody else, to cooperate with the intelligence agencies, and if we do not trust the intelligence agencies, if people think the intelligence agencies have been politicised or have been given excessive powers that they can use without the scope for proper independent judicial oversight, it is actually going to make people a lot less likely to cooperate, not more, and that is against the interests of all of us and against the safety of Australians. So, as we start out on the initial stage of what I expect will be a very heated debate over the next month or so around this whole very important issue of terrorism and security, I do think we need to be very careful about the context in which we conduct the debate, because if we conduct it in such an inflammatory way, then, almost regardless of what the detail is of the final legislation, we will end up with a much more divided society, and that is hardly going to mean a safer society.

talk.start.para: —The question is that the motion to rearrange business moved by Senator Ellison be agreed to.

speech.para: Question agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

motion.para: That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this bill be now read a second time.

speech.para: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

quote.para: This is a bill to clarify our counter terrorism offences.
The Prime Minister has announced that the government will introduce urgent amendments to Australia’s counter-terrorism legislation and to pass those amendments immediately.
The government is acting in response to the assessment that a terrorist attack in Australia is feasible and could well occur. This assessment is backed up by an ongoing flow of credible intelligence.
The Prime Minister has briefed the Leader of the Opposition and the Shadow Minister for Homeland Security on the serious and ongoing concern about potential terrorist threats.
The government is satisfied on the advice provided to it that the immediate passage of this bill would strengthen the capacity of law enforcement agencies to effectively respond to this situation.

The Prime Minister raised this matter in some detail with all of the state premiers and received their unanimous agreement to the immediate introduction and passage of this amendment if the government judged on continuing advice that it was necessary.
The substance of these amendments was originally part of the larger Anti-Terrorism Bill which remains to be introduced.

Given the need to ensure the availability of those strengthened counter-terrorism laws—agreed to by the Council of Australian Governments—we will still need to make decisions on outstanding issues in relation to the larger bill as quickly as possible.

The government is particularly concerned that the whole range of powers agreed to by COAG be available to law enforcement agencies before Christmas and that they be in place well ahead of the 2006 Commonwealth Games.

While the government believes it is important that all elements of the Anti-Terrorism Bill become law within that time frame…. for the reasons the Prime Minister has outlined… the elements of this bill have taken on a greater degree of urgency and as a result, the government intends to secure their passage immediately.
Just to make it very clear—this does not alter the imperative of having passage of the remainder of the larger bill.
The amendments before the Senate today, ensure that the terrorist act offences in Part 5.3 of the Criminal Code are interpreted as they were originally intended to.
They clarify that in a prosecution for a terrorism offence, it is not necessary to identify a particular terrorist act.
The existing offences contain a subsection that provides that a person commits the offence even if ‘the’ terrorist act does not occur.
When the offences were originally drafted, it was not the intention that the prosecution would be required to identify a ‘particular’ terrorist act.
The amendments will clarify that it is not necessary for the prosecution to identify a specific terrorist act.
It will be sufficient for the prosecution to prove that the particular conduct was related to ‘a’ terrorist act.
As agreed by COAG, the bill provides that COAG may review these amendments after five years.
The bill has been considered by the States and Territories which have provided their agreement to its introduction.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —I must say I am a little surprised that the government did not even bother to deliver the second reading speech, given the circumstances—I know the minister incorporated it, but I must say I am a bit surprised.

speech.para: It is rare for the Senate to be recalled out of session. This is something that only happens in exceptional circumstances. I think this is only the fourth time that it has occurred. The last time, in 2003, was when the Senate debated the bill to allow the proscription of the terrorist wing of Hamas. On that occasion, in 2003, Labor agreed to the government’s request to recall the Senate, and we supported the bill due to compelling advice presented by the security agencies. We believed that, in doing so, it was ensured that the right balance was found between ensuring appropriate processes were followed and countering threats to the security of Australians.

The rarity of a recall such as today’s underlines the seriousness of the legislation and the wider situation we are dealing with. Our first duty as a parliament is to protect the security of Australians. We also have a duty to protect our democratic values and institutions. With that in mind, Labor has agreed to the government’s request to recall the Senate today. We are debating this bill today as a result of a specific terrorist risk, identified by our security agencies. The Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for homeland security have received briefings on the specific threat that we are dealing with. As the alternative government of this country, Labor accepts the advice provided to us by the security agencies. The Labor caucus met yesterday and agreed to support this bill.

The amendment makes a minor change to existing legislation—a change which Labor would have supported in any event when the major terrorist legislation was considered. However, it is a change that the security agencies and the government believe is necessary and requires speedy enactment, and we accept that advice. There has, of course, been extensive debate recently about the wider national security legislation that is yet to come before this parliament. The bill that we are debating today is not that wider bill; this bill is a very small part of that legislation. It is a technical change which closes a potential loophole which could have prevented certain terrorists from being prosecuted. As the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Beazley, indicated yesterday, Labor do not regard the material contained in today’s bill as a controversial part of the larger national security legislation. And, as I said, as the alternative government, Labor take the view that we must take the advice of the security agencies and the government in good faith.

Labor does acknowledge the public cynicism regarding the timing of this announcement and the recall of the Senate, coming as it did on the same day as the release of the government’s extreme and divisive industrial relations legislation. I think that cynicism has been expressed by Greens senators in the chamber already. The Australian people are rightly cynical of this government’s approach to national security issues. There is a well-founded perception that the government has not always played a straight bat on these issues.

The Prime Minister, the Attorney-General and other senior members of this government have form on this. These are the people who misled the Australian people over the ‘children overboard’ affair. These are the people who used the refugees on the Tampa as a political tool to improve their electoral chances and who have now been forced, of course, to accept most of those refugees from the Tampa into the country as genuine refugees. And these are the people who insisted on taking us into Iraq on now discredited evidence and with no clear strategy for how to win the peace in that country.

The absolute failure of the intelligence community regarding weapons of mass destruction caused great cynicism in the community. It led to the Flood inquiry into our intelligence services and hopefully will lead to reforms that will improve their performance. Given the daily horrors in Iraq and the increased regional instability that has been caused, I think Australians have a right to be highly sceptical of the government’s judgments. Labor accepted at the time the advice of the security agencies regarding Iraq in good faith, but we continued to argue that we should not act in support of an invasion of Iraq without United Nations sanction. I think that view seems even more sensible as time and events progress in Iraq. I note that many of those who attempted at the time to vilify those of us who expressed opposition to the government’s Iraq policy have failed to correct their own lack of judgment on this issue but rather have sought to concoct a new rationale for our involvement in Iraq.

Australians are also rightly sceptical of the government’s failure to acknowledge that which everyone from Mick Keelty down has recognised—that our adventurism in Iraq has increased the danger of a terror attack on our soil. To acknowledge this is not to excuse Saddam Hussein, to give support to his actions or to apologise for terrorism. On the contrary, it is to make a logical evaluation of the current situation and to assert the absolute necessity of maintaining the highest apolitical integrity of our intelligence services and an approach to national security which goes beyond the day-to-day political needs of the government.

Nevertheless, we are where we are. We have to deal with what we have to deal with. The government and the government’s security agencies argue that this legislation is necessary and urgent. The legislation itself is unremarkable and uncontentious in Labor’s view. Labor would support it on any other occasion. We would have supported it if it was included in the original legislation. We would have supported it if it were contained in the major terrorism legislation that is to come before the parliament in a few weeks time. The government argues that it is urgent. We can only accept that advice, given our obligation to Australian security. People might well express cynicism, but the bottom line is that the government and the security agencies have argued that it is urgent. As an alternative government we have no choice but to accept that argument as part of our obligation to ensure the protection of Australians. It is of course worth noting that the process, in terms of recalling the parliament and dealing with the bill, is a bit on the leisurely side if the threat is so imminent. Of course, one also has to question the effect of this public debate over a couple of days on the operational issues involved. I certainly am left wondering how this impacts on them. But, as I said, the bottom line is we have to deal with what we have to deal with. The legislation is unremarkable, and the advice of the security agencies is that it is necessary and urgent. On that basis, Labor is committed to supporting the bill before us.

I would also like to speak briefly about the question of the Senate inquiry into the wider antiterrorism legislation. Labor has consistently argued that that legislation should face the full scrutiny of the parliament. Proper parliamentary process is essential to ensure that, in framing legislation to counter the terrorist threat, we strike the right balance between a powerful national security apparatus and the protection of the freedoms and values which define us as a society. In several instances over the past few years the parliament, and the Senate in particular, have been successful in finding this balance. It is even a fact that has been publicly conceded by both the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General, despite their earlier criticism of the Senate’s role.

However, the government’s approach to the providing of proper process on antiterror legislation has been less than impressive. At the end of the last sittings, on 13 October, the government exploited a procedural loophole of the Senate in an attempt to avoid a proper committee inquiry into this legislation. It is another example of the arrogance and extremism that has characterised the government since it gained a majority in the Senate. The antiterror legislation has a capacity to cut across the liberties of individual Australians. It was acknowledged by the premiers and the Prime Minister that these were extreme and unusual measures designed to meet new threats. In those circumstances the government’s attempt to bypass proper scrutiny and process was both reprehensible and antidemocratic. It ignored the role of the parliament in creating a community consensus around fundamental changes, and it ignored the record and role of the Senate in identifying and scrutinising faults in legislation—a process, as I have said, that both the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have applauded in the past. The process of Senate committee inquiries and scrutiny of legislation has served the Australian people, our democracy and governments of both persuasions very well. It is not a process that ought to be abandoned easily.

Labor have never argued that we do not need to strengthen our legislative framework to respond to the new threats in the security environment. What we have always argued is that in doing so we should act in a balanced and considered manner. We should observe proper process, provide scrutiny and debate, and ensure that the community is consulted, involved and reassured that the direction we embark upon is the right one. We argue for a full Senate inquiry, and we argue that the laws be passed by Christmas. The Leader of the Opposition has been arguing for strong safeguards on antiterrorism laws since before the meeting between the Prime Minister and the premiers. However, Labor have also argued for sunset clauses, judicial review and parliamentary oversight. We have argued for proper balance. We have argued for more resources for watchdogs like the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security and for new watchdogs, like a national public interest monitor and an independent statutory body to oversight the Australian Federal Police. Labor and the Labor premiers have been successful in forcing some of those changes, and we hope that we can encourage the government to adopt more if the need is proved.

We have been fortunate that the Labor premiers and chief ministers have been able to temper some of the government’s failings due to their undue haste in pursuing these changes. ACT Chief Minister Jon Stanhope’s decision to publish the draft legislation on his web site was, in my view, a courageous one and a move that has significantly improved the level of scrutiny and debate—but it has attracted derision from this government. Public knowledge of the draft legislation is important but it must be supported by full parliamentary scrutiny through a Senate committee inquiry and adequate parliamentary debate. I ask the government to provide reassurance that this Senate will be allowed to have that proper parliamentary debate once the committee reports. But I must admit, given the experience of the Telstra legislation, I am not currently reassured that that will occur.

I think it reflects very badly on this government that it has tried to avoid both Senate committee scrutiny and proper parliamentary debate. As Senator Bartlett made the point very well earlier, it is despicable that senior members of the government sought to characterise calls for proper scrutiny of legislation as reflecting that members of non-government parties were soft on terrorism. It is a despicable allegation. It reflects badly on the government and I think it again reinforces the cynicism that the government seeks to use national security measures and issues for political advantage rather than looking to serve the national interest.

However, I am glad to see today that the government has finally been forced to back off on the question of a committee inquiry, to acknowledge the concerns of the premiers, non-government senators and the public to allow a more detailed inquiry. We will at least now have a proper examination of the legislation by the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee. I think that is a very welcome outcome. This is not as full an inquiry as we might have liked, but it is far better than the one-day farce that Senator Hill initially proposed. I regard it as a victory for democracy. It is a victory for the community, for many in the media, for the premiers, for the opposition and for the minor parties in the Senate. For the government, it is a humiliating retreat. I hope the government will learn from this. I hope that they will see that in being guided by their arrogance, by showing contempt for transparency, consultation and process, they do themselves and our country a great disservice. A Senate majority does not mean unchecked, untrammelled power for the government. The community will respond to the abuse and arrogance that daily seem to increase inside the government. I hope the government will learn the lesson of the community’s reaction to their approach in these matters.

As I say, Labor acknowledges and understands the cynicism of the community regarding the timing of this recall and treatment of urgent legislation, given the government’s record of politicisation of national security matters. However, Labor will again act in good faith today and support the passage of the bill. That is our obligation as an alternative government. We must act with responsibility and meet the obligations that are imposed on an alternative government. We have to make one of our core objectives the security of all Australians. Justification for the urgency of this legislation is a responsibility for the government to explain. All Labor can do is accept that the government’s bona fides are genuine and that the bona fides and advice given by the security agencies are genuine. There is no alternative for us. I think Labor has done the right thing: we have supported the recall of the Senate and responded to the request of the government and we will support this bill.

I want to reiterate for those concerned that the legislation is, in my view, unremarkable and uncontentious. If it had been contained in the previous legislation, it would have passed. If it had been contained in the legislation we are to deal with in coming weeks, it would have been passed. This is not a bill that raises the wider concerns that the community and others involved have expressed regarding the wider terrorism bill and the powers and effect of that legislation. The only issue for us has been the question of the urgency with which it has to be dealt with. All we can do is take the government on its bona fides and accept the advice of the security agencies that have briefed Labor. I understand the difficulties the minor parties have had in this regard. Labor accepts that the government and the security agencies have put a case that it is urgent and we accept that in good faith. Labor will be supporting the bill and we will be supporting the passage of this legislation today.

talk.start.para: —I was approached by the Leader of the Government in the Senate yesterday to be advised that the Senate would be recalled today. Like the opposition and other members of the Senate, I felt in no position to be able to judge whether or not this was warranted and so took the government’s advice that this was necessary and urgent. The question was asked whether Democrat senators would be able to be here. As it happens, one of our number is not. That is because she is sick. But my two male colleagues were able to be here, as was I. So it is not an issue for us in terms of being present for a recalling of the parliament for an urgent matter. However, at that point I had not seen the amendment and certainly had not had a briefing about the imminent threat. Now I have had the former and not the latter, because the Democrats are not entitled to a threat assessment about the security of this nation, unlike the Leader of the Opposition, which in and of itself is a problem in my view. I have had a briefing about the bill. We have had a chance to look at it. We have also had the chance to get some independent advice about its effect, and I am convinced that the Senate has been recalled under false pretences. We are effectively here because the government—I think this is fair to say—is much more interested in heightening the fear that is out there about terrorist attacks than it is about seriously protecting this country.

speech.para: We have a lot of arguments to make against the bills that we will be dealing with in three or so weeks time, but the bill before us, the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005, is not especially scary. In fact, it is a bill that fixes up some relatively minor—although this is arguable, of course—errors in the drafting of the act that is currently relied upon by the government to take action in the case of terrorist activities. The amendments in the bill, as has been canvassed already quite widely, change the wording in the legislation from ‘a terrorist act’ to ‘the terrorist act’. In the existing law, in some instances the reference is to ‘the terrorist act’ and in some instances it is to ‘a terrorist act’, and the amendments in this bill would simply make those references consistent.

I doubt very much that we are here doing urgent business or especially important business. We have to ask ourselves: are these ‘urgently needed’ amendments necessary today? We have already heard advice that the terrorist threat has been known for at least a week and we also know that the amendments themselves have been wanted by the director of prosecutions for at least 18 months. Very early on it was known that those errors had been made in drafting the original legislation and that, at the point at which prosecution might take place in a court of law, there might be a legal argument about whether ‘the’ or ‘a’ would allow someone to get off from the most serious of the terrorist charges.

Do these amendments that we are dealing with today allow the government to act on this week-old advice that a terrorist attack is imminent? The advice that we have received is that they do not. There is nothing to stop the government investigating, interrogating people, laying down charges, making arrests, stopping the action—intervening in any way at all. So this bill does not respond to an urgent situation. It responds to a problem in the current act when it comes to finding a person guilty of the most extreme of those offences.

There is even some doubt as to whether this bill will do that, because there is a question of retrospectivity, and the amendments here are not retrospective. If whatever has been discovered over the last week to be taking place has already taken place, the question is—and I hope the minister will answer this when we get into the committee stage—whether or not these amendments will make the slightest difference. If it is arguable that you have to talk about ‘a terrorist act’ as opposed to ‘the terrorist attack’, being less specific, then that argument will still take place with regard to this current act that we are to be so fearful about.
I think there are real questions to raise in this debate about the issues of urgency and whether or not the government can act. The Prime Minister says:

quote.para: … the Government has received specific intelligence and police information this week which gives cause for serious concern about a potential terrorist threat.

speech.para: I accept that that may be the case. I do not have any evidence one way or the other to argue that point. The Prime Minister says:

quote.para: The Government is satisfied on the advice provided to it that the immediate passage of this amendment would strengthen the capacity of the law enforcement agencies to effectively respond to this threat.

speech.para: I believe that to be misleading, and we can only assume that it is deliberately misleading. The Prime Minister says:

quote.para: We have been given advice that if this amendment is enacted as soon as possible, the capacity of the authorities to respond will be strengthened.

speech.para: Well, no. There is no evidence of that. There is no evidence whatsoever, either in the amendments or in anything that has been said so far, that the capacity to respond—that is, presumably, to stop this imminent attack, to take action which would protect Australians—will be strengthened. The Prime Minister says:

quote.para: … I don’t want to over alarm people; equally I have said for a long time that the possibility of an attack in this country is there …

speech.para: So we have seen a lot of spin: ‘Don’t be alarmed, but be alarmed.’ There is no question but that people will be alarmed if they do not have the details. They cannot weigh up the arguments for themselves to determine whether the threat is imminent or otherwise. As I said earlier, the advice that we have had is that it will make no real, substantial difference to change ‘the’ to ‘a’ in the current legislation and that, at best, it might avoid a legal argument. But the government asks us to trust it in this respect.

It was interesting earlier to hear Senator Hill’s remarks to again attempt to vilify people in this place by saying it is insulting and offensive to suggest that the government is acting out of an ulterior motive. I think we are entitled to do that. I think we are entitled to question the motives of the government, especially when we are not privy to information the government says it has. It is not unreasonable to speculate that there are motives such as getting industrial relations off the front pages of the papers in order to put something else there which puts the government in a better light—although I do not know that this does. A drafting error in a bill seems to me to be a problem that the government should take responsibility for, but there is nothing in the government’s statements, nothing in the Prime Minister’s press release, that admits this.

I think it is likely that the climate is getting hot out there on a number of fronts, not just industrial relations. Over the past week the Uniting Church has come out and sent a letter to all senators—those in this place will have received it. The conclusion of the Uniting Church’s message to us was that the government is acting in haste and that this is unnecessary and could have serious consequences. Mr Stanhope, the Chief Minister of the ACT, earlier this week in a forum which was conducted in the ACT Assembly put out a statement which was headed ‘The bill fails the human rights acid test’. The Centre for Public Law at the University of New South Wales issued a damning criticism of the sedition laws that are being proposed, not in the bill we are dealing with today but in the bills that are coming up in three weeks time. The International Commission of Jurists denounced the ‘terror laws’, as they described them. So I think what we are seeing is a government wanting to get these criticisms out of the public arena so that they are not damaging. I am sure it has concluded that one of the best ways of softening up the general public to accept these extreme laws is to embark again on a fear campaign. That is what we have had over the last 24 hours.

I had a very interesting email from somebody in Tasmania a couple of weeks ago and I am going to read it because I think it has more than an element of truth about what is going on at this time. This correspondent says:

quote.para: Within Australia, since 1996, I have watched the nature of our Government change steadily from basically benevolent to basically authoritarian and controlling. This was accelerated after the 2001 attack on America. Like in America, the 2001 attack seems to have fitted naturally into, and given opportunity to, a pre-existing political agenda. It seems to be moving towards what I would call a “democratic dictatorship”. Secrecy, public manipulation and dishonesty seem to have become widely accepted within Australia as tools of Government.

More recently I have watched with dismay as Australia begins to dismantle the rights of its own citizens. In this case we are told that the “world has changed”, that the old laws are not sufficient to curb terrorism and that the new laws will enable the Government to better fight terrorism.

We are told some of the things that the new laws will allow, that were not previously allowed. What we have not been told, and not had illustrated to us, is just why the old laws could not achieve the required results. We have not been given illustrations of the difference.

Now we have a situation that is open to what one commentator described as “mission creep”. This puts the Government in such a controlling position over its own citizens that, given past dishonesties and manipulation, it would be very surprising if the new laws were not also used to bring dissenting voices into line on many issues not related to terrorism itself. After all, much genuine and required criticism could, without too much conceptual agility, be described as likely to turn people against the Government and towards terrorism.

speech.para: That is an interesting reflection at this point in time when we look at what the government is doing.

I want to finish by talking about the press release which the Prime Minister put out last night and which I think was very persuasive. Quite frankly, the press swallowed this hook, line and sinker. There was not a lot of time to examine the government’s claims, there was not time to have a look at the bill and there certainly would not have been time for them to seek legal advice about some of these provisions. But let us go through it. The Prime Minister’s media release says:

quote.para: The effect of the amendment is to give relevant agencies a greater capacity to respond promptly whenever threats arise.

speech.para: I have already mentioned that that is not the case—there are plenty of provisions in the current bill that do that. But, worse, the government goes on to say:

quote.para: Schedule 1 of the Anti-Terrorism Bill amends the terrorism offences in Divisions 101 and 102 of the Criminal Code, and adds a further ground for listing terrorist organisations in regulations.

speech.para: That is not in this bill; it is not referred to in the bill that we will deal with today at all. So why is it in this document if not to confuse and to frighten people and the media? Towards the end of this media release it says:

quote.para: Similarly, item 10 clarifies that, when determining whether an organisation satisfies the definition of a terrorist organisation, it is not necessary to prove the organisation is preparing, planning, assisting in or fostering ‘the’ particular terrorist act.

speech.para: Again, there is no item 10 in this bill. The bill goes up to item 5. But if you are rushing against a deadline, if you need to get this story out in a hurry, there is a chance you will not pick that up. I think that is what has happened in the reporting over the last 24 hours on what is going on today. I think this is shameful. The government stands condemned for deliberately misleading the media, and all Australians by virtue of that, about what is in this bill and why we urgently need to deal with it and pass it. It is not insulting and offensive for this place to raise these concerns and to question the motives of the government in this case. I think I have made the case, as others have in this place, that there are plenty of arguments that suggest the government’s motives are other than protecting all Australians.

I welcome the government’s agreement to have at least a half decent inquiry into the legislation. I personally do not think the changes that are being mooted need to be dealt with before Christmas, unlike Labor. I think we could have spent much more time looking at them. It will be quite difficult for a comprehensive analysis of what is in the bill to take place. Certainly it will be difficult to pick up errors like ‘the’ and ‘a’ and whether they are consistent or whether they are dangerous, or whether they are going to make it difficult to put people into jail for a life term or something less than that. I do not think we will pick up the errors of that sort that the government makes. But it does at least give an opportunity for the criticisms that have already been aired to be brought before the committee for a more detailed examination of this enormous set of provisions. And it does, fortunately, give the media an opportunity to look at that and to report accurately and with more detail than they have thus far been able to do or would have been able to do with a one-day inquiry, which is grossly and insultingly and offensively too short for any reasonable inquiry to take place. So I do welcome that, and the Democrats will very much be part of that inquiry. I hope the committee receives many submissions and that those submissions assist us to understand what would appear to be the very serious consequences of the bills that we will deal with in a few weeks time.

It is not the place now to discuss those provisions. What we are dealing with here is, as I said, a fairly minor set of amendments that fix up some sloppy drafting. I was fortunate, unlike Senator Brown and the other Greens, to have a briefing on how the amendment will work. I had the ability to question Mr Ruddock’s department on the amendment and to raise a lot of questions. As I said, as a result of that I was not persuaded this was urgent. I was not persuaded it was in any way a substantial amendment. And I certainly was not persuaded that we could not deal with it on Monday, or even in three weeks time, or even next year.

talk.start.para: —The Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005 is so important that 38 of the 39 Liberal senators are missing from their seats. This legislation is so important that the government’s urgent need to extend the shoot to kill provisions in the law to include innocent people on the run has been supplanted. That is urgent, but not so urgent as to call the Senate back. The government’s need to hold people for up to 12 months under house arrest without charge is urgent, but not so urgent. The government’s need to raise the penalty for urging disaffection against the Prime Minister and this government from three years to seven years is urgent, but not so urgent.

speech.para: The supreme urgency before this parliament today is replacing the word ‘the’ with the word ‘a’. That is what we are doing here. When we look into the need for that at a legislative level, it becomes a farce in itself. If we look at the terrorism provisions of the Criminal Code, we find first of all that people who are getting together to talk about creating evil acts in our society can be charged with conspiracy. That is logical. They could be arrested right now. But if it comes to the terrorist provisions in section 100.4 of the Criminal Code, we find that the provision for charging people with terrorism includes:

quote.para: (b) all actions ( preliminary acts ) that relate to terrorist acts ...

speech.para: That covers the range of acts that we are told by the Prime Minister might be about to be perpetrated in Australia.

Let us make no bones about this: this is an absolute abrogation of the expectation that the Prime Minister of this country will treat this parliament with dignity and, what is more, that the Prime Minister of this country will treat the people of Australia with honesty, dignity and responsibility. That is not the case here. The Senate has been recalled, and this ‘the’ for ‘a’ legislative concoction has been raised to an unprecedented level of urgency because the industrial relations legislation was dumped on the House of Representatives yesterday.

We do not know what the terrorist act is that the Prime Minister would have us all believe must galvanise the nation’s attention, but we do know about another terrifying act by the Prime Minister of this country—that is, the industrial relations legislation now before this parliament. We know that it is going to leave people in the workplaces of this country disadvantaged like they have not been for a century. It is terrifying that people in the workplace are going to be left without the backing of unions when they fight for a fair go in the workplace and that people totally disadvantaged through education imbalance, language imbalance and age imbalance are simply going to be left to the mercy of the millionaire CEOs, who are going to get rich out of that legislation while poor people get poorer. But the bosses will do the wrong thing under that legislation, which we read on the inside pages of newspapers because this terror tactic of the Prime Minister has taken the front pages and which will allow companies to sack people for operational reasons—that is, for any reason they like. There is no comeback. It is about to be rammed through this parliament because the Prime Minister has a majority in both houses.

It is a black day in prime ministerial abuse of the people of this nation and their parliament. It is tawdry. It is disgusting. This Prime Minister is not acting in a moral way. This Prime Minister is not acting with due deference to the people of Australia and their rights. This is a manipulative Prime Minister abusing the trust that this country should have in its prime ministerial office. He has done it before; he is doing it again. People say, ‘It’s cynical to question the Prime Minister on this.’ No, it is not; it is looking at form.
