When it comes to terrorism we have to wonder and worry again that we have a Prime Minister crying wolf. That in itself has terrific implications for a country which prides itself on its democratic right for people to be informed and to trust their elected representatives not only to be able to handle information about threats to the nation but to be able to do so in a judicious way which is not coerced, is not back-footed and is not in any way subservient to intelligence agencies who come forward with threat assessments.

Let us look at that. We have the ASIO report telling us that for years we have been under constant threat domestically and externally from would-be evil people who want to create violence and disruption in our society. If we were to contact ASIO for a briefing, we would find that every day of the week a number of individuals and organisations are under surveillance in this country—and so they should be. If we were to inquire further, we would become worried about what those people are up to, because at the end of the line some of them at least would be up to plotting harm against Australians.

As members of parliament and representatives of the people, we have to have the savvy to go beyond that and to insist that we be specifically told what is different regarding this particular revelation about some goings-on in Sydney or Melbourne compared with other revelations about goings-on in Sydney and Melbourne last week, last month or the year before. I will tell you what is different, Mr Acting Deputy President: industrial relations was on the Prime Minister’s agenda yesterday. He knows that the Australian people are fearful of the industrial relations legislation and there is only one fear he could trump it with, and that is terrorism.

So we have this concocted situation where the Senate is recalled and the debate in the House of Representatives yesterday—that extraordinary opposition yesterday—went to the back pages and off the headlines. This is a clever, conniving Prime Minister. This is a Prime Minister whose interests come before those of the nation, whose political savvy has become a political advantage against the interests of this country. This is a Prime Minister who knows how to get his political way. There is one thing he needs to make that easier still, and that is a compliant opposition. And boy, has he got it! He has a compliant Leader of the Opposition in the Hon. Kim Beazley. Has he got an easy, knock-over ally when it comes to situations like this! I say to the Leader of the Opposition: you have failed in your responsibility to ensure that the Prime Minister does not get away with this manoeuvre.

A moment ago Senator Evans, representing the opposition in this place, said that the rarity of the recall underlines the seriousness of the situation. Really? We were recalled for one reason, and that is because the government has got the numbers. It is nothing to do with seriousness; it is to do with political advantage for the Prime Minister. Can the opposition not see that? Has the Labor Party become so feckless that it does not understand that this manipulative Prime Minister will keep them on the back foot all the way down the line unless they stand up to him—and, I suggest, unless some of them start crossing the floor, as their opposite numbers in the United States, the United Kingdom and continental Europe would do in this situation? I suspect we are going to see a total bulwark of the opposition going across to do what this Prime Minister wants this afternoon. I do not expect we are going to get much debate out of this from the opposition, so the Greens and the Democrats become the opposition in this parliament. The crossbenches become the opposition at a time when it is needed.

We must take terrorism seriously, and we do. But we also have a very serious onus on us, in a democratic parliament, to seriously defend the rights, privileges and freedoms that make Australia the country it is. We need to be on the alert for politicians who would sell that and erode it, just a little at the edges, for political advantage now.

When it comes to this particular piece of legislation, my colleagues and I have argued that substituting the word ‘a’ for the word ‘the’ is not a hugely important legal matter. It is not going to make plotters easier to arrest. We are not going to oppose the legislation, if it strengthens the ability, in some way, to prosecute people who would carry out terrorism in this country—and that is a very doubtful matter. Legal advice I have is that you could argue about that until the cows come home. Then so be it.

What is important here today is the manipulation of this whole process in this honourable assembly, in this great parliament, in this freedom loving nation, at a time when we all need to be alert, if not alarmed, that the Prime Minister is on the move and those things are threatened by his actions, as exemplified today. We can only question the government during the committee process—and we will be—as to what this great emergency is. We can expect that the government will keep the lid tight and will not be open with members in here. They are not open with members who are prepared to be briefed off the record and who are quite able and capable and absolutely would treat any information with the absolute security of this nation in mind. No, we will not get answers.

As one specialist in the field, Clive Williams, indicated today, an absolute part of all this is that the Prime Minister knows that this legislation ‘not only works well from the government’s point of view but it also creates a good climate for the new legislation to go through’—that is, the new anti-terrorism legislation. Add to that, as I have said, the industrial relations legislation. Look at the trifecta for the Prime Minister: the Melbourne Cup on Tuesday, this terror alert on Wednesday, and then the whole suite of anti-terror bills on Thursday. It is a trifecta to bury the industrial relations legislation which really haunts this nation, its future and the workplaces of millions of Australians.

talk.start.para: —I have made some of my points already about this situation in my comments earlier today, so I will not repeat those at length. The Democrats support the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005. It is, it has been said by others, including Senator Evans, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate, unremarkable—and it is unremarkable. For that reason, it begs the question: if it is unremarkable, why is it so urgent? Why is it that such an enormous amount of public fear and concern and apprehension has been whipped up quite consciously by the Prime Minister to rush some legislation through this parliament via a special recall of the Senate when the legislation is unremarkable? It is a pretty big and reasonable question, I might say. I think some of us, including me, have already given our opinions on that, but it is something that I think all Australians can form their own views on, and facts are what they need to come to an informed view on that. The problem, as always, is that, when you whip up fear and apprehension about a potential imminent terrorist attack, the facts and simple, rational logic and assessment and analysis tend to be sacrificed.

speech.para: So let us just once again reinforce the facts. This is an unremarkable piece of legislation. It is a piece of legislation the Democrats support. It may, arguably, make it a little bit easier for a successful prosecution of somebody planning a terrorist attack. There is absolutely no way that it makes a difference regarding a police officer or a security official being able to act and their not being able to act by arresting, detaining, charging, questioning or acting in some other way towards somebody who may be in the Australian community at the moment who may be planning some sort of immediate violent act. It cannot in any way be suggested that police or security officials in Australia now do not have sufficient power to act, if they need to do so any time between now and Monday of next week—when the Senate would have been meeting anyway—to prevent a specific act of violence if they have some information that it is likely to be carried out, as the Prime Minister has insinuated.

In that context, once you actually strip away all the rhetoric and look at what this piece of legislation does at law, there is no way that it can make a difference one way or the other in stopping a terrorist attack being carried out between now and when the Senate would have met on Monday. Therefore, you have to ask, if there is some immediate attack pending, being proposed and planned, whether or not the people that might be planning it have been tipped off somewhat by this being consciously and deliberately sprayed all over the front pages of newspapers around the country.

The other point that needs to be made in that context is that the Prime Minister has said, and indeed the Leader of the Opposition has said: ‘We can’t tell you what the threat is. It’s there, it’s real; just trust us.’ It is no secret that I do not trust the Prime Minister. I think he has lost the right to be trusted because he has betrayed that trust so many times, both in a public sense and in terms of the individual commitments he has given to political parties such as the Democrats and even to me individually in relation to matters I have discussed with him in the past. But other Australians may trust him; that is again a personal choice. If people wish to trust him, they can. Obviously, the fact is that sufficient people trusted him to be Prime Minister of this country that they voted for his party’s candidates at the last election. I am not convinced that was terribly wise, but that is what people chose to do and we respect that choice.

As one of the people who are elected to the Senate—in my case, to represent the people of Queensland—I certainly am going to base my decisions on what is on the public record, and the public record of the Prime Minister and indeed others such as the Attorney-General are such that they cannot be trusted in these matters. They have acted in the past in a way which has deliberately politicised and misused our security officials, public servants, public resources and our defence forces. They have deliberately and knowingly misled the Australian people repeatedly on serious matters and they have repeatedly refused to correct the record after having provided information, including information to the Australian parliament, that has later turned out to be false, including on matters as monumental as the rationale for sending Australian men and women to risk their lives fighting for their country at war. That is a pretty poor record.

Dealing with the specifics before us at the moment, the Prime Minister made statements yesterday that there is new information that suggests that there is a serious and imminent threat. I would return to the point I made earlier: in justifying the need for this extraordinary and unusual recall of the Senate, the Prime Minister said that he was acting ‘against the background of the assessment of intelligence agencies that a terrorist attack in Australia is feasible and could well occur’. That is an assessment that has been public knowledge for many years. ASIO has warned that ‘attacks without warning are feasible’. Again, that is something that is almost self-evident but has nonetheless been specifically stated many times in the past. The Prime Minister said:

quote.para: ... the Government has received specific intelligence and police information this week which gives cause for serious concern about a potential terrorist threat.

speech.para: He also said:

quote.para: The Government is satisfied ... that the immediate passage of this—

speech.para: amendment—

quote.para: ... would strengthen the capacity of ... law enforcement agencies to effectively respond to this threat.

speech.para: We still have not seen or heard at all how that could possibly be the case. It is in no way necessary to detail what that threat is and what the information is in order to explain how this legislation, to quote the Prime Minister again, ‘strengthens the capacity of law enforcement agencies to effectively respond to the threat’.

In the second reading speech on this matter, which was so important that the Minister for Justice and Customs could not even be bothered to read it out, that was not detailed either. Whether we will get any explanation to verify the accuracy of that statement by the Prime Minister before the end of this debate, I do not know. I would like to think so, but history suggests very strongly that we will not. The Prime Minister will just make a bald statement that is totally unverifiable, almost definitely false and then just have it reported uncritically as though it is factual.

In addition, in the detailing of the amendments—the very amendments about which the Prime Minister said that immediate passage was necessary to strengthen the capacity of law enforcement agencies—the one part that you might think could be relevant was where he said that this legislation would add a further ground for listing terrorist organisations in regulations. We have already been over this matter today and, indeed, it is in the papers today that there will be a change from the term ‘the terrorist act’ to ‘a terrorist act’. It is very hard to see how that makes a difference in preventing police or security forces from being able to act currently.

You could credibly think that if it is going to add a further ground for listing terrorist organisations in regulations—and the government could then rush through a regulation—then maybe we do need that. And that is what the Prime Minister said this legislation would do—except it does not. It is not there. It is not in this bill; it is simply false. Once again, there is a clear indication of cut and dried, black-and-white, blatant misleading of the Australian people by the Prime Minister about what is going on.

I would also like to look at the specifics of how this has been reported. I have mentioned before about how, conveniently, the Murdoch press, in particular, seem to be able to cooperatively splash this stuff over the front page just at a time when there is a difficult issue happening for the government. I noticed when the Telstra legislation passed a month or so ago that the first extracts of The Latham Diaries that were not going to be released until the following week just so happened to inadvertently be splashed across the front of the Murdoch pages the next day. Perhaps it is a coincidence. Who knows? But once again, just the next day, all we have over the front pages is terrorism. We have ‘Cities on terror alert’ on the banner headline of The Australian. We have: ‘terrorism alert’, ‘terrorists plan attacks, PM warns’, ‘stop evil plot’, ‘fears our suburbs house an evil threat’. That is the sort of thing we get. When we look at the specifics, we find, firstly, the completely inaccurate statement in the Australian that:

quote.para: FEARS terrorists are moving closer to an attack on Sydney and Melbourne have forced the Howard Government to rush through an emergency law to make it easier for police to arrest suspects.

speech.para: I will not bother to dig out the dictionary to remind senators what the word ‘forced’ actually means, but this was a conscious decision by the Prime Minister; it certainly was not forced, and this legislation does not make it any easier for police to arrest suspects. It may make it slightly easier for them to get a conviction on the most serious possible offence, but to suggest that there is no other existing offence under the Criminal Code that they could be arrested on and charged with is just laughable.
Straight under that statement in the Australian there is a comment that the Australian newspaper has learned:

quote.para: ... intelligence relates to home-grown terror suspects in the country’s two biggest cities who are believed to be building the capability to mount an attack.

speech.para: What I want to know is: how come the Australian gets to know all these things about what the threat is, when nobody else does? It is not the first time that this has happened. The Prime Minister, totally above board, of course:

quote.para: ... refused to divulge any details ...

speech.para: But somehow, miraculously, the Australian gets to find out that the intelligence relates to home grown terror suspects in the country’s two biggest cities who are believed to be building the capability to mount an attack.
It was not just the Australian. Just by coincidence, the Daily Telegraph also happened to get some contact from sources, stating:

quote.para: The group under surveillance is made up of Islamic extremists ...

speech.para: and that the suspected terrorists are believed to be based somewhere in suburban Sydney. How convenient! The Herald Sun also gets to find out from so-called ubiquitous government sources about some details of this terrorist threat.

Given how continually and nobly the Prime Minister insists that he is completely incapable of providing any of this information, because that would be grossly improper, I think it is about time that the Attorney-General—that great defender of the rule of law—asks ASIO how it is that all of these newspapers are finding out about this intelligence information that nobody in the community is able to find out about, that none of us here in the Senate are able to find out about. No single person in the Senate is able to find out about this, but somehow a whole range of newspapers are able to find out about the details. When is the Attorney-General going to act? We have a major security crisis here. We have leaks all over the place to newspapers around the country. It is time for the Attorney-General to act. That has to be a security threat if ever I have heard of one—ASIO leaking like a sieve. It cannot be possible.

talk.start.para: —You believe everything you read, Andrew, do you?

—I find it hard to believe but there is the evidence in front of my eyes. The other point I want to make, which I commented on before but which I believe is sufficiently important to re-emphasise, is the context in which the debate is currently being conducted.

speech.para: We had a very positive and constructive event here in Parliament House earlier this week. On Monday night in the Great Hall here in Parliament House—a wonderful venue, as I am sure all senators would know—we had quite a well-attended dinner to celebrate the end of Ramadan. A range of people from the Muslim communities around Australia attended. The people at my table came to Canberra from cities around the country—from Sydney, Melbourne and Adelaide—specifically to partake in that dinner with members of parliament and staff as part of coming together and acknowledging the positive contribution of Muslim communities in Australia and building understanding and bridges. There were people there from all political parties, and I take this opportunity to congratulate Ms Sussan Ley, the member for Farrer, and Mr Harry Quick, the member for Franklin, who helped to organise that dinner, because it was a positive event.

That is why it is so disappointing that the very next day we had front-page coverage based on the ASIO general report, once again, specifically singling out the Islamic community and Muslims within Australia. As I mentioned earlier, the front page of today’s Australian once again reinforces community fears and stereotypes: finding one or two Islamic preachers in Australia and quoting a few comments from them—almost all of which were about Iraq—and using the stereotypical front-page picture to reinforce all of the negative stereotypes. What I found more instructive was coverage inside that newspaper by one of Australia’s Muslim youth leaders: Mr Omran, who is from the Federation of Australian Muslim Students and Youth. Mr Omran said that he believes and fears that people who are speaking on behalf of the Muslim community are being targeted. Whilst he said quite specifically that Australian Muslims have nothing to hide, he also said that a lot of young Muslims already feel the laws are directed at them.

I spoke in this chamber a couple of years ago about how the laws and the political debates surrounding them were already making many people in the Muslim communities around Australia feel targeted, under threat and alienated. That is unfair but it is also counterproductive for all Australians. If we seriously want to get good intelligence about the very small number of people who are potentially planning politically motivated violence, we need to have trust and connectedness between people throughout the Australian community. The more you isolate, alienate, threaten and single out the wider Australian Muslim community, the harder it will be for our intelligence agencies to really find out what is going on.

It might make good shock-jock stuff and good newspaper headlines, but it is dangerous for the Australian community and it is particularly dangerous for Australian Muslims who themselves are saying that they feel singled out and targeted. Government members can mock that all they like, but that is what they are saying. If you want to close your ears to that then you are closing your ears to one of the most vital avenues to give us our best chance for safety into the future. My view is that most government members do not care about that; they are just interested in the political capital they can make out of this situation and are not interested in Australians’ safety.

I probably sound a bit hard on the Australian, so I would point out a good article written by Mike Steketee, who made the very simple point that being tough on terrorism is the easy thing, that anybody can get out there and say, ‘We’re being tough on terrorism; we’re going to give our police more laws and we’re going to cut out the courts. Ultimate powers—we’re tough.’ Anybody can do that. Anybody can pick on the weak and the vulnerable. That is the easy part. The tough part is actually standing firm in the face of terrorism and defending our freedoms against the easy option of giving in. But that is what this government is at risk of doing—and all of these Labor premiers as well. A few small concessions, welcome as they are, are not adequate in the face of surrendering huge amounts of freedoms.

We should contrast this to the decent job that the UK parliament is doing. I note that overnight Tony Blair’s margin of 66 in the UK parliament shrunk down to one over just one amendment to legislation. That legislation, which is being debated in the House of Commons and is still to have a proper, full review in the House of Lords, has already had an initial inquiry as well—far more adequate opportunity for scrutiny than, sadly, the Australian parliament is going to get.

In dealing with this, we need to scrap all of the banner headlines, all of the cheap shock-jock stuff, all of the political point scoring and all of the taking of the easy road. We need to show some guts for once and take some tough decisions to stand firm alongside the entire Australian community, including the Muslim community—who, I might remind senators, have lived in Australia for over 150 years and are here from over 60 different countries, from a wide variety of languages, nationalities, ethnicities and skin colour. They are as diverse as the rest of our community and they deserve as much support as the rest of the community. Let us see a bit of courage and guts from this government, instead of the cheap, easy option time after time—sacrificing our freedoms in the process.

talk.start.para: —Dennis Shanahan in his article today in a major daily says:

quote.para: If the cynics ... are right and the “terror threat” was a smokescreen for the IR laws, Howard’s career will be mortally wounded. This would be a monstrous abuse of power and public faith.

speech.para: I believe it is a monstrous abuse of power and public faith because I do not believe it was necessary for the Senate to come back today to make this amendment. I believe the powers that the government is seeking are already there in the legislation that exists in this country.

So why do I say that it is a monstrous abuse of power and public faith and yet I disagree with Shanahan when he says that the Prime Minister would be mortally wounded if this legislation were demonstrated to be a smokescreen? It is because the Prime Minister continues to play the Labor Party as suckers in this regard. I do not know why we do not have a grand coalition in this country, as is being attempted elsewhere in the world, because every time the Prime Minister wants to legitimise outrageous behaviour, he has a secret meeting with the Labor Party and after the secret meeting the Labor Party comes into both houses of this parliament and says, ‘We in the know, in on the secret, now agree with the Prime Minister and we will go along with whatever we are told.’

What is the point of having houses of parliament if you only have to have a backroom meeting which gives you some information which you base your decision on? You do not tell the Australian people what is going on; rather, it is ‘wink wink, nod nod’, and those who need to, know. The problem for the Labor Party will be after the next election, when there will be a balance of power restored to this chamber—which I believe will occur at that time, as the Australian people are already regretting the fact that the government has a majority in both houses. At that point, how will the Labor Party respond if the government of the day—if it does not happen to be the government of the day—does not brief them and only briefs the people it considers it needs to get something through? Then they will say: ‘Oh, dear. The opposition hasn’t been told. We’re expected to come here and make up the numbers.’ It seems as though it is okay as long as the Labor Party is told. Nobody else in the house needs to know. It is on a needs to know and secret basis.

This is about legitimising what the government wants to do. Why? Because it spreads the blame. When the Australian community find out that this is a monstrous abuse of power and public faith—yet another one on the behalf of the Howard government—the Prime Minister will be able to say: ‘It wasn’t just me. The Labor Party agreed that we had to have this special sitting of the Senate and that this was an urgent matter. We shared with them what we knew and they agreed.’ It is about spreading the blame, legitimising an abuse of process and cutting out the role of the Senate as a house of review and as the scrutineer of what the government does. It is an outrageous abuse of democracy and certainly it is an abuse of the other parties in the Senate, who are not deemed to be able to know what the government and now the Labor Party know.

They did precisely the same thing when a person—his name was Scott Parkin—was taken off the streets, thrown into detention and then deported from the country. When we tried to have a debate about that in this house, we were told that the Prime Minister had a private briefing with the Labor Party and, now the Labor Party understand that Mr Parkin was some sort of security threat, they agree that it was okay for him to be deported. I have no idea about Mr Parkin. I have never met the man or spoken to him. But I know there was an obligation on the government to justify what was essentially an abuse of the rule of law.

We have got to a situation here where the fear factor is not so much in relation to terrorists—who of course have to be condemned—rather there is an equal and growing fear of this government. As I have said in this chamber before, there is a sticker out in the UK at the moment which says: ‘Love my country. Fear my government.’ Every time that this cynical abuse of power and abuse of public faith is brought on by the Howard government, people must be getting more afraid.
Why would they be getting more afraid? Do you remember this?

quote.para: The Australian government knows that Iraq still has chemical and biological weapons and that Iraq wants to develop nuclear weapons.

speech.para: So said the Prime Minister, John Howard, on 4 February 2003. He said:

quote.para: Iraq continues to work on developing nuclear weapons—uranium has been sought from Africa that has no civil nuclear application in Iraq ...

speech.para: He also went on to say:

quote.para: The Government has decided to commit Australian forces to action to disarm Iraq because we believe it is right, it is lawful and it’s in Australia’s national interest.

We are determined to join other countries to deprive Iraq of its weapons of mass destruction, its chemical and biological weapons, which even in minute quantities are capable of causing death and destruction on a mammoth scale.

speech.para: He was wrong on every single count and he committed Australian troops to Iraq. I want to put on the record that nothing is heightening the threat of terrorism to Australia more than the decision of the Prime Minister, John Howard, and his government to go into the war in Iraq and his unswerving backing of the Bush administration.

You only have to look at the David Hicks situation and what happened overnight. Even the Kuwaiti government has had the courage to demand that its citizens be returned from Guantanamo Bay and be dealt with in Kuwait, but the Australian government has not. The British have their citizens back, the Kuwaitis have got their’s back, but not the Australian government. Why? Because we have an unswerving commitment and belief in the justice of the American system. It has so much justice that the Americans set up their camp in Guantanamo Bay so that they were off American soil and so excluded from the provisions of law.

This is about basic matters, like civil liberties and the rule of law. We have had a number of people in the judicial system around the country expressing grave concern about what is going on. But before I get to them, I want to remind the Senate that the UN Secretary-General, Kofi Annan, launched a fierce attack on Britain and the US earlier this year for weakening human rights in the name of the war on terror. He said:

quote.para: We cannot compromise on core values. Human rights and the rule of law must always be respected.

speech.para: He went on to say that a UN special envoy to monitor whether governments’ counter-terrorism measures conformed to international human rights law should be established. He said:

quote.para: Compromising human rights cannot serve the struggle against terrorism. On the contrary, it facilitates achievement of the terrorist’s objective—by ... provoking tension, hatred and mistrust of government among precisely those parts of the population where he is most likely to find recruits.

speech.para: That is the UN Secretary-General in a not very thinly veiled attack on what was going on in Britain and the US in regards to undermining human rights in the name of this so-called war against terror.

It should be the ‘fight’ against terror because, as international jurists have said, to describe combating terrorism as a war is not only misleading but also dangerous. The term ‘war on terrorism’ instead of ‘fight against terrorism’ plays into the hands of perpetrators of terrorism. At the same time, it confuses the terminology applied in international humanitarian law and jeopardises the applicability of human rights standards.

I want now to refer to a speech that was made by the Hon. John von Doussa, who is a QC and the President of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission. He has looked at these new laws that are coming in Australia. He says:

quote.para: It sounds over dramatic to say that the proposed laws are of the kind that may identify a police state, but let us reflect for a moment on this proposition. The defining characteristic of a police state is that the police exercise power on behalf of the executive, and the conduct of the police cannot be effectively challenged through the justice system of the state. Regrettably this is exactly what the laws which are currently under debate will achieve.

The Government’s response to criticism of the wide ranging powers given to them by the ASIO laws has been, in effect, to say: ‘Trust us. We are a responsible organisation, and we would only ever use these heavy powers if they were really necessary. We must have these powers ...’

speech.para: The difficulty with that approach, as experience has shown not only in places like South Africa but also even here in Australia, is that reality turns out otherwise. The revelations of the Palmer report demonstrate how abuses of power occur where there is no accessible and realistic way that people can question what is happening to them. What happened to our trust in this situation? What happened to Cornelia Rau’s and Vivian Solon’s trust? Do they still trust our government? Can Scott Parkin say that he could trust the Australian government?

We have had the Prime Minister defending his position on the basis of what is going on in the UK but failing to point out that in the United Kingdom they have a very powerful Human Rights Act. In addition to the UK Human Rights Act, they have the European Court of Human Rights. So there are other bodies to which people can appeal. In this country we have no bill of rights, no human rights act and no court of human rights to which we can take any of our concerns.

We are here today having been brought back, in my view, on a completely false premise. We are brought back on the basis that this is such a terrifying situation that the Senate must meet. Look at this chamber—it is almost completely empty. If the citizens of Australia actually believed there was really a major terror threat facing one of our major cities today, I wonder if they would have expected an almost totally empty gallery and an almost totally empty Senate. It is a cynical exercise, as I said—a monstrous abuse of power and public faith—with the Labor Party roped into the coalition’s game. What they have effectively done is destroyed their own capacity to raise the profile of the industrial relations legislation by going along—with a wink, wink and nod, nod from the Prime Minister—in relation to this matter.

If the threat was so serious the laws are already there that make it a crime to conspire. To conspire is already a crime under the existing legislation. There was nothing to stop the Australian authorities acting the minute that this threat was made known to go and deal with it. The action and the capacity are there. There is legal advice to say that is the case. The Prime Minister did not act when he was told about this because the Melbourne Cup was on Tuesday. Instead of that, he waited until after the Melbourne Cup and after Australia had had its big day of celebration and then he recalled the Senate, so that the front page stories would all reflect the concern about terror and the language of it.

Language influences behaviour—we all know that. If you start to use the language of fear, you whip up fear in a community. Fear is a strong motivating factor. You have words all over the papers today like ‘fear’, ‘evil’, ‘terror alert’ and the suburbs ‘harbouring criminals’ and ‘harbouring terrorists’. It is designed to frighten the average person in the street. It is softening them up, if you like, for the legislation that the government is trying to bring in in a couple of weeks time. But in fact the power already exists. That is the point. There has been nothing said by the government. The fact is that the government did not even read the second reading speech. It incorporated what was said in the House of Representatives yesterday into the Hansard and did not even bother reading out the speech today. It cannot even be bothered having its members in here to engage in the debate. Instead of that, we have the ultimate abuse of power, with the government controlling both houses, and the acquiescence of the Labor Party, which, I believe, should start negotiating for a grand coalition after the next election because then we would clearly have set down where we have a government and where we have an opposition.

I would like to conclude by saying that during the time of my education people reflected for a long time about what happened in Europe during the war. As a child I was quite fascinated by the history of that period, being a part of the baby boomer generation. I could never understand how it was that decent and good people who knew what was going on did not do anything. That is why I have been so alarmed about the Scott Parkin matter. There are decent people in Australia who are currently turning their backs and not wanting to know how it is that someone can be just dragged off the street, put into detention and deported from the country. Everyone says that is okay because he was identified as a risk. If there was a risk, he should not have been given a visa in the first place. If he was a risk, they should articulate what the risk was, not just to the Labor Party but also to the man himself. He did not even get told what he was charged with or what he was accused of. His lawyers were not told. He was just deported. That is terrifying to me. It is Scott Parkin today; who else will it be tomorrow? Under these laws the whole concern is about being able to take people out of the community, accuse them of something and put them into detention, and everyone else just keeps on with their day-to-day existence as if this is all right and the rule of law, international human rights and our global obligations can all just be set to one side because a government says that this person is a risk.

I keep with me something that became etched onto my brain at one time. I have thought about it for years since. It was particularly pertinent during the campaign for gay law reform in Tasmania. It stays with me now in terms of this legislation. It says:

quote.para: First they came for the Jews
and I did not speak out
because I was not a Jew.
Then they came for the Communists
and I did not speak out
because I was not a Communist.
Then they came for the trade unionists
and I did not speak out
because I was not a trade unionist.
Then they came for me
and there was no one left
to speak out for me.

speech.para: I am reminded of that with Scott Parkin. I am reminded of that with the industrial relations legislation currently in the lower house. If I am fearful at the moment, I am fearful for the rights of ordinary Australian people out there in the community. I fear for them because we have a government out of control. We have a government which is exercising a monstrous abuse of power and public faith.

talk.start.para: —Once again, we have seen the use of the terror trump card. But there will only be so many times you can use this. When my son was small I used to read to him the story of the boy who cried wolf—and, boy, is that ever relevant today. I cannot express the dismay I felt yesterday as I heard that the Senate was to be recalled, and for what reason. The contempt that was shown for this place and for the people of Australia, by trying to trick them into believing that it was absolutely essential to recall the Senate, and that we needed to mask the debate on IR, fills me with dismay. It fills me with dismay that that is what they call democracy now in this country.

speech.para: It is my understanding that the Prime Minister received notice of this apparent terror threat well before the industrial relations bill was tabled yesterday. Why, then, did they go ahead with the introduction of the bill before introducing the terror amendments? If, as has been argued, there is an immediate threat that needs such urgent action as to recall the Senate, why was it not so urgent that this was introduced, if not days before, at least before the IR legislation? And if, as they claim, these changes are absolutely vital to enable our security forces to deal with the threat then why didn’t the Prime Minister introduce these changes much, much earlier? They should have cleared the deck for such an urgent matter as national security. We already know that our security forces have known about the issue and the need for this amendment for some time. They have been calling for these changes, I understand, for 18 months. It was not our security forces that initiated these actions halfway through the introduction of the IR legislation; they raised these concerns a long time ago. As I said, I understand the Prime Minister knew at least 48 hours before.

The kinds of errors that this legislation is being introduced to address happen exactly because legislation is rushed through parliament and cannot get the review that is needed. I am deeply concerned that, as other legislation is pushed through parliament and through the Senate where guillotines and gags are used, we will see a lot more problems with legislation. This is why we need proper debate and to allow time for proper consultation.

I condemn the government’s cynical manipulation of the fear of terrorism for what I believe are political purposes. Announcing the recall of the Senate to address an amendment on terror laws only hours after the introduction of the major changes in the IR legislation can be viewed as nothing but a cynical attempt to divert the Australian public’s attention away from these draconian changes. It clearly exposes the government’s manipulation of the threat of terrorism for the basest of political ends.

The government are seeking to avoid scrutiny of their devastating attack on the rights of working people. I articulated earlier some of those rights that they are removing, and some of the changes: changes that will see people sacked for no reason, take away the disadvantage test, threaten safety, give the minister unprecedented powers, demolish our award system and reduce conditions to enshrining five—five—conditions in legislation. What happened to all the rest of them that Australian workers take for granted these days? It is an erosion of our rights and conditions by legislation, not an enshrining of our rights in legislation.

The government allowed no debate and no consideration of the claim that these changes are being introduced for the so-called reason that they will increase productivity—there is no evidence to support that claim at all. We have had no time to look at that. And the media are not covering that. The media are covering the terror laws and the immediate threat. The massive changes that are coming in as a result of the IR legislation deserve public attention and debate, and it is an insult that Australians have not been given that right now. I also note the comments by the ASIS intelligence operative, Warren Reed, that appeared in today’s Australian. He declared that the—

talk.start.para: —Former.

—If I didn’t say former, I meant to. He declared that the Prime Minister’s timing was exquisite, and decried the fact that ‘politicking was colouring national security’. And, of course, these sorts of things are not new. The same issues came to light over weapons of mass destruction.

speech.para: If this is, as is claimed, a serious and urgent matter, then it should not have been compounded and confused by being introduced on the day the IR legislation was introduced. It should have been introduced earlier. To call those of us who are raising concerns about this un-Australian and to imply that we are soft on terror is an insult—an absolute insult—particularly to those of us who hold nonviolence and peace so dear and so fundamental to all that we do. It is an insult to Australians, who deserve a full public debate and who elected us knowing full well what our principles were and knowing that we would stand up for them.

We are told that we have to trust. Well, I am sorry; the trust book is all used up. The trust bank account is all used up; it is empty. There is no longer room for us to trust what we hear from the Prime Minister and the coalition, that we should trust them that this is a problem, when we have heard so many things that have been wrong before.

As I said earlier, this is using the terror trump card, and you will not be able to use it much longer because Australians are getting cynical, just like we are cynical about this use—abuse—of the parliamentary process to ram through changes: changes that could have been made a while ago, changes that we do not absolutely need right now, because the legislation is there to deal with this. It does not allow a full debate in the full context of these issues, and it is undermining the beginning of the debate on the IR legislation.

I am confident—or at least I hope—that Australians will see through this cynical attempt, will see what is happening, will see the abuse of this process and will see that these IR reforms are an unprecedented attack on the workers of this country, on the trade union movement and on the rights and conditions that Australians take for granted. We are not opposing this particular amendment, but I am dismayed, and I feel a sense of shame, that the parliament has been abused in this way.

talk.start.para: —Labor senators are here today to support the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005. The government assures us that this bill is urgent and essential. A responsible opposition has no choice but to trust that a government would never use such a device for political gain. In the case of John Howard’s government, that trust has so often in the past been betrayed. But we have to take the government at its word. We cannot gamble with Australian lives, and we will not play politics with national security. This Senate needs to understand that Australians are at greater risk today because Australia’s involvement in the Iraq war has made our country less safe. Mr Howard’s decision to join that war was as grievous an error as any Australian Prime Minister has ever made, and that grievous error was based on a lie. The consequence of Mr Howard’s catastrophic misjudgment is greater danger for each and every Australian. This legislation has been brought to the Senate today in an effort to avert that danger. Soon we will be dealing with far more wide-ranging security legislation—legislation that can be fairly called draconian. Again, the government justifies itself by referring to the increased possibility of violence here in Australia. Yet never once does Mr Howard acknowledge that it is his own government’s actions that have brought that danger to our shores.

—I am unaccustomed to hearing Senator Faulkner speak so briefly. Since I have been dragged across the continent to pass the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005, I would have felt obliged to talk on the bill anyway, just to justify the effort. I will use the occasion to make remarks on the question of our liberties, but first I will talk about this bill. Records and first-time events are always interesting. In 104 years, I think this must be the first ever special recall of the Senate just to change one word in one piece of legislation. In fact, in the grand spirit of this momentous moment, the Senate should bring this to the attention of the Guinness Book of Records. I suspect they would confirm that this is the first time in the recorded legislative history of mankind that any country anywhere has recalled its legislature specifically to change one word in one piece of legislation. But what a word! ‘The’ must be changed to ‘a’,’ the Prime Minister roared. ‘I agree,’ squeaked the opposition leader: ‘Now. Yesterday. Send helicopters!’ ‘No, calm down. Qantas will do,’ said the Prime Minister.

speech.para: Qantas could not rustle up a connecting flight at short notice, so I left at 13.20 Western Standard Time on Wednesday. I had to sleep over at Melbourne airport, and I got to the Senate 16 hours later, this Thursday morning. But I would do anything if it meant changing ‘the’ to ‘a’. This, after I got home to Perth on Tuesday at midnight Eastern Standard Time after two days of Senate finance and public administration estimates committee hearings. On Wednesday morning in my Perth office I was greeted with the breathtaking news that I was called back to Canberra for a special Thursday Senate hearing to change the definite article ‘the’ to the indefinite article ‘a’. I knew then that this must be really, really serious. I knew then that the fate of the nation must be at stake. Changing that word would definitely stop any terrorist in their tracks. I could see the mullahs going out and finding Osama somewhere in his lair and saying, ‘Stop! Stop! The Senate has changed “the” to “a”!’

This definitely could not wait four days until Monday, when the Senate sitting was scheduled. These four days will make all the difference, won’t they—even though the terror alert stays unchanged, exactly where it has been for four years; even though right now we have laws that can see anyone intending a terror act grabbed, nabbed, charged and denied bail under conspiracy or individually. This bill will surely make all the difference, won’t it?

If in the next four days no-one is charged under the new law, we will know it is just politics and posturing, designed to exaggerate a public fear and to put pressure on the Labor Party and the Labor premiers—it seems to be an easy thing to do these days. It is about power and politics, that is all—same old, same old. It is not about an emergency at all. It is just another exhibition of group think. It is just another manipulation of the gullible. What is needed instead is a heavy dose of good old Aussie cynicism and disbelief. Where are all the political cartoonists and satirists when you need them? Where are the journalists prepared to shout, ‘The emperor has no clothes’?

I saw a comment the other day trying to place terror in the scale of things the government must address. Statistically, terror deaths and injuries may well rank far behind the death toll from alcohol, drugs and tobacco related consumption, from asbestos and chemical exposure, from road trauma and from suicides caused by paedophile priests and paedophile others. But the government and the public are still right to take terrorism very seriously indeed. I support them taking it seriously, and that is why I object to and resent them not taking it seriously with this display today. I object to and resent them minimising and trivialising what is a very serious matter. I support maximising our ability to respond effectively to terrorism within the boundaries of the rule of law under the principles of liberal democracy. I support us maximising our efforts to address the causes of terrorism. I support this bill too, minor as it is, even if I do find this recall four days early to deal with it a contrived and pathetic overreaction.

I am not going to attempt to address the new antiterrorism legislation today. That will, thankfully, now be better addressed by a Senate review process originally intended to be shortened to 8 November but now given an extra three weeks. When I turned to Senators Bartlett and Stott Despoja on the Senate floor that day and said, ‘Go for 28 November,’ I am glad they did and I am glad we succeeded.

What I want to say briefly is that intellectual and legal analysis of the antiterrorism legislation needs to be accompanied by the dominance of values and beliefs—of liberal democratic values and beliefs, not conservative values and beliefs, not authoritarian, antilibertarian values and beliefs. It is not strength to turn back on our legacy. It is not strength to undermine and diminish the protections we have. It is not strength to give the police powers which cannot be reviewed by the judiciary or restrained under review. It is not strength to create secret police or political police. That is weakness. Strength is standing up for our traditions, for our conventions, for all the things that the soldiers and sailors and airmen of Australia have fought for through several wars. Strength is defending our liberal democracy and its values and the rule of law.

We have marvellous police women and men but you cannot take the idiot factor out of large groups of people. There will be a minority who will abuse powers. There will be a minority who will behave in a way which will result in harm to members of the community. There will be a minority who will make mistakes. That is why you want the separation of powers. That is why you want the rule of law. That is why you want police integrity commissions. That is why you want review processes. That is why you want judicial oversight. That is why you want warrants being granted only by the judiciary and magistrates. That is why you need the protections, because there is always a minority who abuse power. Everyone in this chamber, everyone in this country, knows that there has been a royal commission into the police in just about every state of this country. Everyone knows that the majority of police men and women do a wonderful job but that a minority caused those royal commissions. Everyone knows that innocent people have been convicted because of standover tactics, mistakes and abuse. If you give people powers and you do not have the proper protections and controls over those powers, you have a problem.

What has offended and concerned people who defend the liberal democratic values on which this great country is founded is that the government is asking us to trust and give powers to people who have proven in the past that they do not warrant being given that trust and those powers. They need, for their own good as well as for ours, the protection of the rule of law and of habeas corpus. I will repeat that: of habeas corpus, which all our fathers fought for, and for the ability of people to be considered innocent until proven guilty in a court of law under our system. It is not weakness for me to stand and repeat those tenets of liberal democracy. That is strength. What is weakness is to override them and to try to confuse people that what you are about is in fact preserving the very rules that you are violating.

I want to give you an example. I am ashamed to say that it is an example from my own state. I am ashamed to say that it is from a person who was educated at my university. I am ashamed to say that it is of a person whose intellectual history, knowledge, training, education, principles and beliefs should rule otherwise. I am talking about Geoff Gallop, the Premier of WA. WA’s Terrorism (Extraordinary Powers) Bill 2005 proposes that the police commissioner can issue search warrants if a person in any jurisdiction has grounds for suspecting that a terrorist act is going to be committed. This means the police commissioner—or, if the police commissioner is unavailable, anyone down to the position of superintendent—can issue a warrant without an objective assessment of evidence simply on someone’s personal suspicions. This proposal offends the fundamental protection afforded us by the separation of powers and the independent judiciary. Only judges or magistrate should issue warrants.

There is also no provision for a review of this decision even if it is later shown that this personal suspicion was false or nonexistent. Clause 20 unambiguously says that the decision to issue such warrants cannot be:

quote.para: ...appealed against, reviewed, quashed, challenged, or called in question, before or by any person acting judicially or a court or tribunal on any account or by any means.

speech.para: This is absolutely outrageous. This is not a fight between the Labor Party and the Liberal Party or between the crossbenchers and the other parties. This is a fight by people who support, protect and defend liberal democracy against those who are conservative and authoritarian from any party. It is absolutely outrageous.

Premier Gallop has said that this legislation is to protect WA’s unique lifestyle. Nonsense! It strikes at the very heart of what makes WA a great place. It attacks a fundamental aspect of a civil society. Such powers are typical of a police state, and we should not be making WA into one. People too easily say, ‘You can’t raise the issue of a police state in a country like Australia.’ Yes, you can, if the powers given to the police are equivalent to those powers which are characteristic of tyrannies or of police states.

I have said here before in this place that I am very much marked by my past. I do not stand here as a novice in these matters. I know what banning and detention without trial is. I know what house arrest is. I know what it is like to live in tyrannies and to talk to people who have gone through the effects of tyrannies. Those tyrannies are not tyrannies because the majority of police in those countries are bad people, but because the minority abuse things and secret police turn into political police, because political power is exercised wrongly through what should effectively be a protective and defensive body.

I am a very strong supporter of good strong laws which enable us to stamp on terrorism in this country or any other, but I am also a very strong defender of the proper protections that should be there against the abuse of power, against the innocent being locked up for days at a time, against turning a blind eye to torture or standover tactics, against the judiciary not being brought into play to watch over these matters. I am as aware as anybody else that there are a number of politicians or judges or policemen or people of any nature who are likely to be less than heroic in their ethics or values. I am as aware as anybody else that standing behind every dictator and tyrant in the world have been rank after rank of judges and lawyers. I do not put great faith in a judge or a lawyer being an automatic protection, but, when you set the judiciary and the legal system on one side and you have the police on the other, then you have the proper checks and balances. What we are in danger of doing in these debates, in defending our country from this current threat, is overturning the great wisdom and values and decency of Mr Menzies and Mr Curtin and people who, out of the Second World War, knew that great tyranny means you must defend the very basics of liberal democracy.

I am taking the opportunity today to express my concern about the underlying problem with what has been put before us. The problem for us all—the crossbench, both sides of the house, and the public—is that we all want terrorism dealt with, but the people look to us to at the same time safeguard their general rights and protections, and underpinning all this antiterror legislation is a march against our liberties, which will mean that innocent people will be in danger.

Thank goodness there are great members of the Liberal Party, great members of the Labor Party and members of the crossbenches who are prepared to work to try and ameliorate the worst effects of what is being proposed. Thank goodness the Senate will now have a period of review and reflection. I know people throughout all the houses, and they are fine people, but for goodness sake they must not just march into line. They must not just submit to group-think. They must not become forelock-tuggers. They must defend what is important to this country and to our democracy. They must prevent the Terry Lewises of the world being given the power to issue warrants to allow superintendents below them to conduct search and seizure actions. They must prevent a situation such as there is in New South Wales, where a policeman who acts wrongly cannot be brought up before his peers for proper judgment, simply because issues of terror are involved. They must prevent people being detained without trial. They must allow for public monitors and for proper videoing and recording of all interviews. They must permit visits during the detention period. They must allow immediate family members and legal representatives to be advised of what has happened, because if that does not happen it is the innocent who will be affected.

This is why most parliamentarians oppose the death penalty. Many more parliamentarians support the death penalty in their hearts than will vote for it, because they know that about a third of all people who ever get the electric chair were not guilty in the first place. Mistakes happen. You cannot take the idiot factor out of the system and you cannot take the malicious out of the system, so you have got to have the proper checks and balances and the proper safeguards. The purpose of my remarks today is to encourage those who can hear these words and who might be affected by these words to allow the intent of the terror legislation, which is to prevent and to minimise terror, to go through but to retain within the legislation the protections and safeguards which are absolutely essential in what has been a great and liberal country.

talk.start.para: —I have been involved in many debates—about 30 now—on pieces of antiterrorism legislation in this parliament. This one is certainly the most rushed and the one for which we have had the least explanation about why parliament and the Senate are being asked to do so. The changes that are outlined in the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005 are designed to broaden the scope of various terrorism offences that are contained in the Criminal Code. Are they necessary and are they urgent?

speech.para: We have had some discussion already about whether or not they are urgent. It appears they are urgent enough to bring the Senate back to change one word. They are urgent enough for the Prime Minister to move to ensure that the front pages of the newspapers are not about the changes to industrial relations and people’s workplace arrangements which the Prime Minister does not want on the front pages because he knows people are frightened by them. But they are not urgent enough for the Prime Minister to do anything about them at the time of the Melbourne Cup when he had this information. And they are not urgent enough for the Prime Minister to do anything about bringing in the legislation before the industrial relations changes are introduced, as he could have done if they were so urgent.

Are they necessary? Today on ABC radio we heard from Rob Stary, one of Australia’s most experienced criminal trial lawyers, who is currently involved in a number of security cases around ASIO raids that occurred in June this year. He spoke about the way in which the courts are already currently interpreting the wording of our Criminal Code and terrorism acts in the way in which the government claim to be amending the legislation. So we have a government claiming that we need these amendments in order that the legislation is clear and they can prosecute people. They already have enormous powers, and I will talk more about those shortly. But for the specific powers they want now they say, ‘We need to make this clear so that it is clear to the courts.’ Yet a lawyer involved in current security cases is saying that the courts are already interpreting the law the way the government are claiming they want the law to be interpreted. He is not the only one of our top lawyers speaking out and say these changes are not necessary. A senior counsel, Brian Walters, is also quoted in today’s media saying that these changes—changing the word ‘the’ to the word ‘a’—will not make a jot of difference. So we have senior lawyers and lawyers involved in these cases saying the courts are already interpreting the legislation in this way. Yet we have the Prime Minister calling the Senate back for what he says are not just urgent but necessary changes. The case has not been made for them being either urgent or necessary.

These changes lower the bar for any prosecution to prove a case in any trial, although, as I say, lawyers involved in these cases say that is not needed. It is not credible that the changes are needed to allow the arrest and charging of anybody remotely connected with a terrorist act. The existing Criminal Code already contains extremely broad offences of terrorism that do not rely on the evidence of a specific terrorist act. I said before that the Prime Minister needed to get himself a copy of the Criminal Code and have a look at what is in there. I will do that now. I will turn to the section of the Criminal Code which says that the code, specifically the part of the code that relates to terrorism, applies to the following conduct:

quote.para: (a) all actions or threats of action that constitute terrorist acts (no matter where the action occurs, the threat is made or the action, if carried out, would occur) ...

speech.para: The parts of the Criminal Code that relate to terrorist acts also apply to the following conduct:

quote.para: (b) all actions (preliminary acts) that relate to terrorist acts but do not themselves constitute terrorist acts (no matter where the preliminary acts occur and no matter where the terrorist acts to which they relate occur or would occur).

speech.para: There are extraordinarily broad powers. And that is just one section of our Criminal Code that relates to terrorist offences.

If I go right to the front of our Criminal Code and have a look at the table of contents for the terrorism section of the code, it lists the offences that are already covered by our Criminal Code. They include: terrorist acts, providing and receiving training connected with terrorist acts, possessing things connected with terrorist acts, collecting and making documents likely to facilitate terrorist acts, other acts in preparation for and planning of terrorist acts, directing the activities of a terrorist organisation, membership of a terrorist organisation, recruiting for a terrorist organisation, training a terrorist organisation or receiving training from a terrorist organisation, getting funds to or from a terrorist organisation and getting support to a terrorist organisation. All of these things are set out in our existing Criminal Code as a result of changes and terrorist legislation passed by both the major parties in this parliament about 1½ to two years ago. It is all there. What do the police have the power to do? They have the power to detain people and to question people, and ASIO can question them, for seven days. These people do not have to be suspects. They can just have information relating to a terrorist act. That is what our current criminal law says. That is the power our government currently have. So it is all guff about the need to change the word ‘the’ to the word ‘a’ in order for us to be able to do anything about a likely terrorist threat.

What do you think all the other 30 pieces of antiterrorism legislation that have been passed in the Senate since September 2001 were about? They have given our government extraordinary powers: the power to detain people without trial, without taking them before a court, for seven days to question them. These are extraordinary powers. That is what the government have got and yet they say: ‘No, we need more. And we don’t just need more today. We need more before Christmas—we need a whole lot more before Christmas. We don’t want to detain people just for seven days. We need to detain people for 14 days. In fact, we want to lock people up in their houses and stop them from using a telephone or the internet for a year. That is the power we need.’ That is what our government are telling us. It is not just that today we have to be called back here to change the word ‘the’ to the word ‘a’. That is not good enough for this government and for the security agencies. They need more powers than the already extensive, draconian, extreme powers that they have that undermine fundamental tenets of our legal system, that do not allow for proper judicial review where people can test the merits of a case and can go before the court and argue: ‘I am not a terrorist.’

That is not what the government are proposing. That is not the kind of scrutiny or oversight that they want. We will be back here again and again. Whilst this issue of terrorism and fear continues to work for this government they will drag us back in here and ask us to give them and their security agencies more power. We have already had comments from people like John von Doussa from the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission saying that the proposals being put forward take us not just towards but to being a police state. We already have senior members of our judiciary telling us that—and they have not just been telling us that recently; they have been saying that for years—and this parliament, both the major parties, has been giving our security agencies more power for years. And we are here again today to give our security agencies more power.

The police and ASIO have the power to detain anyone they say has information regarding terrorism. It is clear, regardless of what happens in the coming days, that the timing of this legislation is all about spin—hyping the terrorist threat and distracting attention from the attacks on fundamental rights contained in both the industrial relations changes and the coming antiterrorism laws. Over the weekend and the next week we may see somebody arrested and charged with offences, which the government could have already done. We may see pictures of dramatic raids and information leaks about the accused to the press. But the Australian people should and will be sceptical.

If these changes were so urgent, why not move them at any time since they were first envisaged 200 days ago? If the Prime Minister had new information on Melbourne Cup Day, why didn’t he recall the Senate yesterday or last night to pass them before the industrial relations legislation was introduced? Why didn’t the police and security agencies use the existing and extensive laws of conspiracy or one of the broad offences in our Criminal Code to arrest and charge people they believed were planning a terrorist act? Why haven’t they already done that?

The Australian people have learnt that we cannot trust this government and often we cannot, unfortunately, rely on or trust the advice of intelligence services. What about the intelligence and the lies on weapons of mass destruction in Iraq? What about the lies of the ‘children overboard’? What about the arrest and deportation of peace activist Scott Parkin based on an adverse security assessment by ASIO—a security assessment that, by the way, ASIO admitted this week in Senate estimates did not have anything to do with any evidence of violence. What about the bungled raid on the Sydney family of Bilal Daye and his wife, who had only been in the country for four days? What about the bungled ASIO raid that occurred just weeks after 11 September 2001? There was going to be a court case this week in which they had put in a claim for $1.5 million in damages from the Commonwealth, ASIO and the Federal Police. It was settled out of court because it would not have suited this government to have a debate about that bungled raid that they carried out on this young family in Sydney just four days after the young woman had arrived in this country. They barged into the house and would not allow her to get properly dressed and, as they knocked on the bedroom door, they said, ‘We’re going to blow this off.’ It would not have suited the government to have that court case going on now, so it has been settled out of court. Of course, it is secret, so we do not know for how much.

This government is more concerned about using the fear of terrorism for political ends than addressing the real root causes of terrorism. If this government were serious about addressing the threat of terrorism, they would get Australian troops out of Iraq and they would urge the Americans to leave as well. If this government were serious about addressing the root causes of terrorism, and Islamic fundamentalism in particular, which they continue to point out, they would urge Israel to resolve the conflict with the Palestinians by ending the occupation. If this government were serious about fundamentalism and terrorism, they would seek a positive engagement with the situation in Kashmir rather than taking sides. They would support measures aimed at addressing inequality and poverty in the world. Our aid program would be used and prioritised for poverty alleviation rather than the governance and security features that are currently so central to our aid program in our region.

Over the last three weeks we have had an unprecedented debate about the importance of civil rights in Australia. The public outpouring of opposition to the antiterrorism laws, despite the lack of leadership from the opposition, has been enormous. Not one significant legal figure has backed the government’s proposed antiterrorism laws. The Law Council, former judges and former prime ministers have all attacked the laws. As I said before, the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission president, John von Doussa QC, has said the laws will make Australia into a police state. The laws, even in their amended state and supported by Labor, will still allow someone to be detained without charge or trial for up to 14 days by police and in their home for up to a year. Remember, as I said before, these are not people convicted of any offence; these are people the police do not have sufficient evidence to charge with any offence.

The new sedition laws proposed in the legislation will attack the right of free speech and threaten to close down debate on issues like Australia’s involvement in the war in Iraq. The rushed bill we are considering today is all about pre-empting the debate on these attacks on our fundamental freedoms.

Before I finish, I want to quote something that was said in the House of Representatives in the so-called debate on this legislation yesterday. Four people spoke and only one person expressed concern about these issues—that was the Independent member in the House of Representatives for the seat of Calare, Peter Andren. I quote from his speech because it applies today in the Senate. He said, quoting Ian Barker QC:

quote.para: Today we are on the edge of a slide into our own 21st century form of fascism: secret arrests, secret detention, secret interrogation by secret people.

speech.para: That is what these antiterrorism laws are about, and today is a part of that.

I foreshadow that during the committee stage I will be moving an amendment that has been circulated in my name on behalf of the Australian Greens. I will not speak to that amendment now; I will speak to it when we move into the committee stage of this bill.

I want to conclude by saying that we are all here today because we all care about this country and because we want to protect our friends and our colleagues who are in this country. The Prime Minister should not abuse the faith and strength that we all have in being here, and I believe that he is doing that today. We as senators are not here to rubber-stamp more draconian security laws like the 30 pieces of legislation that have already gone through this Senate. This is another one, and he wants a whole stack more to go through in a couple of weeks. That is not what the Senate is for. That is not what democracy is about, and I and the other Australian Greens senators will have nothing to do with it.

talk.start.para: —in reply—The Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005 is to clarify our counter-terrorism offences. It is urgent and much needed. When one talks about the duty of the Senate, there is no more serious duty than to look out for the interests of our nation, particularly those relating to security. The Prime Minister announced yesterday that the government would be introducing these urgent amendments and passing them immediately. The Prime Minister has stated that he consulted with premiers and, on two occasions, with the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for homeland security.

speech.para: The reason for this bill is one which is serious and which has the full support of our law enforcement and security agencies. The government has received specific intelligence and police information this week which gives cause for serious concern about a potential terrorist threat. The government has not yet received any information that would require a change in the general terror alert level for Australia but will respond appropriately if such advice is received. Further action in relation to the threat is a matter for police and intelligence agencies. It is, however, the responsibility of government and the parliament to respond when credible advice is given, and these laws are designed to meet the threat and strengthen the capacity of the authorities to deal with the situation. Members of the public, I stress, should not be alarmed. These measures are to assist our operational agencies to have the full power to protect Australians from the ongoing threat of terrorism.

A number of points have been raised by senators, and I will deal with those in turn. But I can say that the information we have is credible and we have relied on the advice of our security and law enforcement agencies in taking the action that we have. And, of course, the Prime Minister has acknowledged the cooperation of the premiers and the support of the opposition in this regard.

I turn now to a number of points which were made in the course of the second reading debate. One point was that the Criminal Code already provides sufficiently for such offences. Senator Nettle said that there are a range of situations which are covered by the Criminal Code. What she failed to acknowledge was that, when you look at section 101.1, the first description of ‘terrorist act’ says:

quote.para: A person commits an offence if the person engages in a terrorist act.

speech.para: You have to go on to section 101.2 subsection (3), which says:

quote.para: A person commits an offence under this section even if the terrorist act does not occur.

speech.para: By using that phrase ‘the terrorist act’ you are indicating a specific act. There is a particularity, a specificity, if you like, which cannot be escaped. What we are talking about in these amendments is replacing the word ‘the’ with ‘a’, which would be a more general description of behaviour. That is, any act which would go towards a terrorist act, any financing of a terrorist act, or the possession of implements or items of property which would go to a terrorist act, could be caught. That will enable our authorities to deal with a situation where the particular terrorist act may not yet have been identified but where a group of people may be planning a terrorist attack but have yet to determine where, when and in what form that attack will be.

Under our criminal law, when you charge a person you have to have a particularity in relation to the charge. That is, the indictment, or the complaint if it is in petty sessions, cannot be void for uncertainty. You have to prove intention to do a particular act. In the security environment that we are dealing with, you may well have a situation where a number of people are doing things but you do not yet have the information which would lead you to identify a particular act. That is really what this is all about. We have taken advice on this from our law enforcement agencies, our security agencies and the Director of Public Prosecutions.

I am not going to comment on particular cases which are pending before the courts or the possible defences that could be raised.
