But I can say that it is not uncommon at criminal law to have a defence where someone raises at a committal proceeding or a trial that there is no case to answer because the act complained of has not been particularised in an appropriate form. When you are dealing with security, you have to keep an eye on prevention of the act itself as well as bringing those who are guilty of the act to justice.

A number of senators have asked why we did not do this some time ago when we looked at the enactment of previous counter-terrorism laws and at the current terrorism package. This provision was and is contained in the current antiterrorism package, and it has been the subject of discussion with the states and territories and has been described as one of the least controversial, if I can put it that way.

This amendment clarifies the original intention of the legislation to remove any doubt that a person can be prosecuted for a terrorist act and acts preparatory to a terrorist act, and that our agencies can investigate such acts even if a specific target has not been identified. What the government says is that, if you go back to section 101 and section 102 in the Criminal Code, you will see how the wording referred to ‘a’ specific terrorist act but then went on in other subsections to refer to ‘the act’, which then narrowed the application. We would say that, with the experience now of the advice received from people like the DPP, law enforcement agencies and others, we have learnt that this needs to be cleared up, to be put beyond doubt, so that our law enforcement and intelligence agencies can act with appropriate power to protect Australia’s interests.

Someone has said, ‘This is all a sham, it’s a stunt,’ that it is something which was just thought of to divert attention from other matters. I totally reject that. That is a very cynical approach to what is a very serious matter. This is something which has been part and parcel of an ongoing discussion about a counter-terrorism package but it is in relation to the advice that the government received this week. The Leader of the Opposition and his shadow minister for homeland security have been briefed on that information, as well as the premiers, and they all support the course of action that we are taking. They support the recalling of the Senate and the urgent action that we have taken. They do so in the full knowledge of the briefing that they got, not from the government but from agencies such as the Australian Federal Police and ASIO.

That is a very telling point, because there are a number of people who would have the Australian community believe that this is a cynical exercise, a political exercise, not one which is aimed at protecting Australia’s interests. While we are on this point, can I just refer to the words of the Premier of Victoria, Mr Bracks, when he made the following observation:

quote.para: Well, look, the advice we’ve received, this does appear genuine, and obviously, you know, we would not support any action on a legislative change going through the federal parliament as a matter of urgency unless the briefings were sound and solid, and I think to suggest otherwise would be to bring into disrepute the Australian Federal Police, Mick Keelty, ASIO, other agencies who would have to be part of that arrangement, that timing—and that is fairly difficult to arrange—and I don’t think they would see themselves as part of any government agenda.

speech.para: What Premier Bracks was saying there was that he trusted the advice he got, the briefing he got, and that the agencies who were part of that briefing would not be party to any political stunt, and that the timing of this is indeed one which is genuine in substance, and the advice which goes with it is equally so. That is not coming from the government, the Prime Minister or the Attorney-General; that is coming from the Labor Premier of Victoria.

Some other matters have been raised as well in this debate. Senator Bartlett said that we were scaremongering, in particular scaring the Muslim community. At the outset, can I say that the government’s counter-terrorism laws concern those who engage in terrorist activity and no-one else. These laws are designed to protect the community and there is no greater intrusion on one’s rights than to be the victim of a terrorist attack where you may suffer serious injury or, even worse, where your life is taken.

The Prime Minister’s meeting with the Islamic community recently, in late August, is an example of how the government is committed to working with all of those individuals and groups who wish to preserve our freedoms and prevent extremists from dividing our nation. This meeting represented an exchange of ideas between the government and the Islamic community. The Minister for Citizenship and Multicultural Affairs convened a Muslim community reference group, which is part of the continuing dialogue arising from the Prime Minister’s summit. The government has already commenced planning a number of initiatives, including communication training for Muslim community leaders and a series of youth summits. These issues, of course, are very important, and the government recognises that we cannot deal with them just in one piece of legislation. That is why we have embarked on a broader program of dealing with the Muslim community. I totally reject Senator Bartlett’s assertion that in some way we are scaring the Muslim community.

Senator Bartlett also said that newspapers such as the Australian seemed to know about the threat but no-one else did. I found that a curious comment. I think that it is certainly a dangerous premise to rely on any particular newspaper in the country having knowledge which is correct in this matter. In fact, we have to be very careful, in looking at a situation such as this, that we do not believe the first thing that is printed. That is why the government have told the community to remain calm and not be panicked by what has been said. But, at the same time, we have a duty to act and to take preventative action.

Senator Nettle, I think, mentioned that this was merely an extension to the existing terrorism offences legislation, and that is not so. As I said earlier, this amendment clarifies the original intention of the legislation, to remove any doubt that a person can be prosecuted for a terrorist act and acts preparatory to a terrorist act and that our agencies can investigate such acts even if a specific target has not been identified. And that really stems from the original wording of sections 101 and 102, which I have referred to, of the Criminal Code.

One thing I do need to correct—which I certainly reject—is that Senator Bartlett alleged that the Prime Minister has almost certainly made false comments. This is, I think, an unfair comment. It is a very difficult position that the government is in, and the Prime Minister in particular yesterday was at great pains to say that we have had this information as to a potential threat which is specific. But he could not go into the details when pressed, obviously, because we are not going to signal to those who want to bring harm to Australia what we are about or what we are doing. It gets to a point where we cannot comment on matters because they are operational. That happens frequently in relation to matters such as criminal investigations. The Prime Minister was quite right to approach it with the caution that he did. It does not show that he is hiding anything; it is merely the responsible way to deal with what is a very serious issue.

The bill also has contained within it not just the amendment that I and others have referred to but a review of anti-terrorism laws. That reflects the Council of Australian Governments’ agreement on 27 September that the council would, after five years, review the operation of the amendments. That is a demonstration of good faith in relation to abiding by that agreement made at COAG.

The comments from those who have contributed to this debate that there are existing police powers which can deal with the situation are unfounded. Indeed, the Canberra Times stated that there are police powers—powers to arrest and powers to obtain a warrant—which could be used in this case. Without the interpretative amendment that we are proposing in this bill, there is room for doubt as to whether the police would be able to rely on the terrorist offences in the Commonwealth Criminal Code, which I have outlined, to make an arrest in circumstances contemplated by the Canberra Times in its editorial and as stated by other senators. That is precisely why we have introduced this amendment today, and it is the reason for the urgency.

The final point involves appropriate safeguards in relation to the activities of the police. A number of commentators have stated that they are concerned as to safeguards in relation to scrutiny and accountability in relation to the Australian Federal Police and others who would act pursuant to the amendments. I place on record that the Australian Federal Police has an extensive accountability framework for its actions. That includes both internal and external scrutiny of its officers. Key features of this framework include a complaints process oversighted by the Commonwealth Ombudsman which is provided for by the Complaints (Australian Federal Police) Act 1981, the Ombudsman’s oversight of the Australian Federal Police’s use of powers available under the Telecommunications (Interception) Act 1979 and the Surveillance Devices Act 2004, and the Australian Federal Police’s accountability to parliament through the annual reporting and Senate estimates processes. We recently saw the Australian Federal Police Commissioner questioned at length in the estimates process.

The government is committed to strengthening this framework. We have already announced funding for this initiative and will be introducing, in the first half of next year, a bill for an Australian commission for law enforcement integrity as an independent body to proactively identify, investigate and respond to matters of corruption within Commonwealth law enforcement agencies. That will further strengthen the accountability and scrutiny of the Australian Federal Police. So I say to those who are concerned that there are extensive aspects of scrutiny in place in relation to our law enforcement agencies and that is already built into our system.
This is a very important bill for Australia and the protection of our interests. It is a matter which requires urgent attention and I commend the bill to the Senate.
Question agreed to.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I ask the minister: is the threat that is being dealt with here imminent and serious?

—Certainly the Prime Minister has said that we have received advice from our agencies that is specific and we take it very seriously. As a result of that, we have taken the action which is well known. But as to commenting on the operational aspects and the question of it being imminent in its proximity and what has been threatened, I am not going to go into that. That would be an operational matter which would be inappropriate to discuss in a committee of the Senate. But I can say that we certainly take the advice that has been given to us very seriously. It is credible and it is of such a nature that this response is needed.

—We are getting a lot of evasion about the timing of the threat. When I used the word ‘imminent’ I meant in regard to time, not in any other regard. I cannot see why the minister cannot answer that. We are not asking what the Prime Minister said in public; we are asking what the advice to the minister is. So I ask again: is the threat that is being dealt with here imminent? I also ask: when was the issue of this new threat first raised with anybody in the government?

—Of course, briefings were given this week. That has been stated by the Prime Minister. In relation to the aspect of evasion, we have made it abundantly clear that we are not evading any aspect of this; in fact, to evade it would be to do nothing. What we are saying is that, if we go into details of when, where and how, you could well alert those who mean to do harm, and we do not intend to do that.

speech.para: In relation to the advice that has been given to the government, the Prime Minister and the Attorney-General have stated that it is backed by an ongoing flow of credible intelligence. As to the point in time that the government was first made aware, I do not think that it is appropriate to go into that at this stage. Again, that could well signal aspects of this matter, and it would be inappropriate to do so, for the reasons that have been stated previously. I can say that the briefing that has caused this action was given this week.

talk.start.para: —The minister indicates that he cannot give a statement as to when the government knew about this, although the briefing was given this week. But already that indicates that the government knew and information was flowing about this before this week. I would remind the minister that this week began straight after midnight on Saturday. I think that there is a very careful choice of words being used here, but what the minister indicates now is that, while the briefing was given at that time, information was flowing before then.

speech.para: The minister says, ‘You could well alert those who mean to do harm.’ What an absolute joke that is! Here we have headlines all across the country and a news saturation like we have not seen for many months, even with this government, except in major overseas events, and the minister says, ‘We can’t answer questions in this chamber because it might alert people who want to do harm.’ That is a nonsense. It might alert people to the manipulations that this government has been involved in. The minister said a little earlier that members of the public should not be alarmed—remain calm. Really? With headlines like ‘Stop the evil plot’ and ‘Cities under threat’? The government is treating the Australian people with a great deal of disdain in this matter. Apparently, terrorists do not read the Herald Sun or any of the other newspapers in the country. The second paragraph of the Herald Sun article headed ‘Terrorists planning attack, PM warns “Stop the evil plot”’ says:

quote.para: The immediate and unspecified threat came from an Islamic extremist group centred on Sydney, Government sources told the Herald Sun.

speech.para: Which government sources told the Herald Sun that?

talk.start.para: —I think that I made it very clear in my reply during the second reading debate when I referred to Senator Bartlett’s comment about the Australian that no one paper had a mortgage on the detail of what we are talking about here. In fact, I think I said in the debate we just had that we should be very careful as to what we believe is written in the paper. I do not in any way confirm or acknowledge that what the Herald Sun has written is correct.

speech.para: I reiterate that the government has received specific intelligence and police information this week which gives cause for serious concern about a potential terrorist threat. That is a very straightforward statement. I do not think I can be clearer than that. This detail has been provided to the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow minister for homeland security. Briefings have also been given to the premiers. As we all know, they are not of the same political persuasion as the government; yet they fully support the action that we are taking. I am not going to comment on newspaper reports and I am certainly not going to enter into any debate as to the accuracy of them or otherwise, but I do say that people should not be panicked by reports covering this issue. It is a serious issue, but it is one that should be handled in a rational manner.

talk.start.para: —I have no concern with the newspapers reporting what government sources tell them, but what I do have a great deal of concern with is the strategic leaking by this government of information coming from ASIO. The government will not tell the Greens or the Democrats or most other members of parliament—although it might tell Labor premiers—what the imminent threat or non-imminent threat is, but it leaks the information to the nation through selected journalists. I think if that happens it is illegal. But, whatever, it is a gross manipulation by this government of the fear of terrorism. It is an extraordinary set of circumstances that members of parliament cannot be briefed but government sources—that is, the Prime Minister’s office and the Attorney-General’s office—leak information from ASIO briefings to the media to engender fear. And the minister comes in here and says, ‘Remain calm.’

speech.para: Why is this manipulation of public opinion through selective leaks occurring? It is occurring because the industrial relations bill is in the House of Representatives on the same day. What a disgusting government this is! What a disgusting process this is: selectively leaking to heighten the fear about terrorism to divert attention from the terrific consequences of industrial relations. And the minister comes in here and says, ‘But members of the public should not be alarmed,’ with the Prime Minister having got headlines all over the country. The Prime Minister got his way: ‘Terrorists planning attack, PM warns.’ And the minister comes in here and says, ‘Remain calm.’ This is duplicitous. On the one hand, you are frightening the daylights out of everybody and grabbing all the headlines and taking attention away from industrial relations, while on the other hand you are telling everybody—with that soothing voice—‘Stay calm, everybody. Trust us.’ I have not seen the likes of this before. And the Labor Party falls into line because Kim Beazley, the honourable Leader of the Opposition, gets a briefing. I do not know why the government did not try us down here. It might have had no debate at all.

You see, this is high political strategy that is occurring here. Has the government been warned about people talking about terrorism and about people conversing about terrorist attacks over the last several years in this country? Of course it has. The ASIO report indicates that there are a number of these occurring at any given time. People are being watched. There are regular briefings to the government about that. But something changed this week, and a special briefing was brought on because the industrial relations legislation was coming down the line. Can we expect arrests in the wake of changing ‘the’ to ‘a’? No, do not expect that, says the Attorney-General. What about the tail-off in this new surge of terror news in the country? Bring in the full suite of legislation today—that will keep it going for a few more days. We are seeing a very clever strategy here from the government. It has two big pieces of legislation the Prime Minister wants through before everybody goes off to their Christmas shopping: industrial relations and these antiterror laws. The one is being manipulated to keep the other off the radar. These are not ordinary claims, but they are substantially backed up by the evidence.

And we read this selective leaking in the papers. Has the Prime Minister done anything about that? Were the police brought in today to find out who is leaking into the public arena—yet again—selected government-assisting information from ASIO for the umpteenth time in recent years? No. It will take a letter from another Ben Oquist, somebody outside this parliament, to draw it to the attention of the inspector-general. I ask you, Minister: has the inspector-general been asked about government sources leaking to the press that an Islamic extremist group centred on Sydney is the matter of concern here? Is the inspector-general going to investigate that?

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I should place on the record that I totally reject the allegations made by Senator Brown that the government has been in the business of leaking national security information or any information at all which would relate to the security of this country. I totally reject that. The allegation demonstrates the absolute cynicism with which Senator Brown approaches this argument. To engage in such a leak would constitute an offence. If there is anyone, including Senator Brown, who has information in relation to that, they should refer it to the Australian Federal Police. Maybe the journalist concerned would like to reveal his or her source—and I am sure Senator Brown would support that.

speech.para: In relation to the inspector-general, he makes decisions independently as to what he will look into. He is not a person who is directed by the government to do anything. I know Senator Brown wants us to direct the inspector-general, but any decision by the inspector-general is an independent one. If anyone has information, which they can bring to the attention of the authorities, on which an investigation can be founded, they should do that.

talk.start.para: —It is on the front page of the paper.

—As I said earlier, Senator Brown and Senator Bartlett seem to place great credence on newspapers in their assessment of matters of detail regarding national security. They seem to accept that everything they read is correct in that regard. I have already said that the government do not acknowledge that as being correct and do not adopt or confirm it in any manner. We totally reject the outrageous allegation that the government has been in the business of leaking sensitive information. As I said, if anyone has any information in relation to that, they should bring it to the attention of the authorities and action will be taken.

—On the Nine Network today, terrorism expert Clive Williams, who heads Canberra’s Strategic and Defence Studies Centre, said that the potential threat revealed yesterday may involve a person who trained with the listed terrorist organisation Lashkar-e-Taiba—which as we know is proscribed—in Pakistan. Mr Williams said:

quote.para: ‘At this stage, as I understand it, the activity is largely in the very early planning stages. It’s two persons in Sydney talking to others in Melbourne about potential targets,’ …

‘One of the persons apparently was identified by an American informant as having attended an LET—a Lashkar-e-Tayyiba—camp in Pakistan, and they’ve been talking to others in Melbourne apparently about what sort of targets they could attack.
‘So it’s sort of very early stages and that’s why the Government wants to change the law in the way it does.’
Dr Williams later told ABC Radio that police conducted three raids in Sydney in June in relation to the threat and the suspects had identified targets in Melbourne.
‘I believe that [the suspects] had videoed some potential targets in Melbourne,’ he said.
Dr Williams said the Government’s decision to announce the legislative change might have compromised the ability of authorities to charge the suspects.

speech.para: Let me quote that again:

quote.para: Dr Williams said the Government’s decision to announce the legislative change might have compromised the ability of authorities to charge the suspects.

speech.para: Dr Williams went on to say:

quote.para: ‘To change the legislation you had to have a reason for it and the prime minister had to come forward with some reason for doing that, which is what he’s done’ he said.
‘At the same time of course it’s now compromised the operation and means that it’ll probably be very difficult to get a conviction.

‘The alternative of course was to allow it go through to the point where there was specificity as to time and place, but then there’s the danger of it getting closer to actual fruition, so maybe the Government didn’t want to take that chance.’

speech.para: What about putting this through in the normal course of events over the last 18 months since the issue was first raised? The only thing we can make of that is incompetence in the government in the face of this ‘Alert but not alarmed’ message that the government has been telling us about. So it is a mixture of incompetence, selective leaking and illegal acts, on the face of it. The minister just corroborated that. We have it on the front page. I asked him whether he will put this matter to the inspector-general and he said, ‘Somebody else should do that.’ This is a government that is very manipulative and very selective. If Dr Williams is right, it is one that has also, in the events of the last 24 hours, ‘compromised the ability of authorities to charge the suspects.’ It has done the very opposite to what we are supposed to be doing here today. How do you like that! And why? To give the Prime Minister political leverage and to put the industrial relations legislation off the agenda.

The Prime Minister has actually compromised the ability of the intelligence agencies to make an arrest or avert a terrorist attack by this mishandling of the public process and this parliament through this recall of the Senate today. What an extraordinary situation that is! Recalling the Senate is actually a break for the terrorists, because they have been told that the intelligence agencies are on their tail. It is obvious, isn’t it? The callers to talkback radio are pointing it out. Did the Prime Minister not work this out for himself? Of course he did. But the Prime Minister was prepared to compromise the work of intelligence agencies and the police in this country to get a political advantage. Whichever way you look at it, it is tawdry politics, it is manipulative and it is certainly not in the interests of this country.

talk.start.para: —Senator Ellison has referred to some of the comments I made in his responses to some of Senator Bob Brown’s remarks. I think it is important to emphasise the key point that is being made here. It is not whether or not the specifics of what is in the Herald Sun, the Daily Telegraph or the Australian happen to be specifically correct. I do not expect the minister to confirm or deny the specific details that are in these papers. Certainly all of us here can easily make references to whether or not you should believe everything that is in the newspapers. The simple fact is that either the minister can guarantee that no government source has provided information, correct or not, to these newspapers or the newspapers are making it up. I would suggest that, if the newspapers are making it up, there are a few different newspapers and a few different journalists so it would be a bit strange if they were all making the same thing up. But they are all News Ltd newspapers, so it is possible, I suppose. Either these people are all making it up or they have all been provided with some information.

speech.para: The minister himself said that it would be illegal for any information about this intelligence material to be provided to the media or anybody else. It is illegal to provide it to other members of the Senate and to people in the general community, so I am sure, as the minister said, it would be illegal. I do not know if it is illegal to leak information that is actually false and misleading. Obviously, the journalists involved would not know if it was true or not. I certainly do not blame them, I might hasten to add, for reporting what they have. It is appropriate that they do so.

The simple issue here is not whether what is there is accurate, because none of us are in a position to know that. Probably not even the journalists are in a position to know whether or not what they have been given is accurate. It is whether or not the government and the minister—who, I might remind the Senate, is the minister who represents the Attorney-General in this place—can assure the Senate and the Australian people that there are no government sources leaking intelligence information or purported intelligence information to the media, because, as the minister himself said, that would be a serious matter. It is not just a matter of trying to catch the government out or catch the media out or whatever. It would be a serious matter if any government official, government source or ministerial staffer were leaking intelligence information or purported intelligence information to anybody. As we are repeatedly being reminded in this place, we could not possibly let other senators know about this detail, yet it has ended up on the front page of the newspapers.

The minister also responded to me in his concluding remarks by saying it was outrageous of me and the Democrats to suggest that this is targeting Muslim people. It is not me saying that Muslim people are feeling targeted; it is the Muslim community saying that they are feeling targeted. If you do not want to listen to that then you should. How is anybody living in a Muslim community in Western Sydney going to feel when they read in the newspaper that this is all about an Islamic extremist group centred in Sydney? They are not exactly going to feel comfortable and relaxed about it. And they do not—I can tell you that.

It does not help at all to have this sort of information, true or otherwise, leaked to the media or to anybody else. It is a serious matter that there is even the prospect that government sources, so-called, are providing this information—whether it is true or whether they are just giving useful tidbits to journalists.

It is not a matter of whether what is here is accurate. I would suspect that Senator Brown, of all people, is not going to go around asserting that everything in the Herald Sun is accurate, given his dispute with them from the last election. I certainly have personal experience of front page headlines in the Herald Sun that I was not particularly appreciative of, but, again, that was just them reporting the information that they were given, which certainly was far from accurate, but you do not blame journalists for reporting information that they are given from government sources because they are not to know whether or not it is accurate.

The simple point here is not whether what is in the newspapers is accurate. It is the fact that, clearly, either a whole lot of different journalists are all just completely making up the claim that they are getting this information from government sources, or else someone in the government is leaking them information that comes from this intelligence matter—or that they are purporting and holding out to the journalists comes from this matter. Either way, that is very serious, and I find it very disconcerting that the minister does not seem to think it is serious and just says, ‘Well, you can’t believe everything you read in the newspapers, so don’t worry about it.’

The government has insisted today, with great mock outrage and hurt feelings, and cries of ‘How could anybody suggest that there is any cynicism involved here?’ that we should all have confidence in our intelligence agencies, and in all of the government’s pronouncements, yet we cannot get a simple assurance or a simple indication that under no circumstances are ministerial staffers or government officials leaking any of this information to the media. If we cannot get something as simple as that, how can you possibly protest when people are suspicious and cynical about what is really going on here?

talk.start.para: —I rise to follow up the minister’s response to Senator Brown about when the government first knew, or was briefed, about this threat. The government has already said that the threat is non-specific in time and place and with regard to action, but it now seems to be refusing to inform the Senate as to when it was first alerted to this threat. It is a very important question, because the government has tried to put a case that this threat, this matter, is so urgent that the Senate had to come back today to deal with it and that Monday, when the Senate was due to sit, would have been too late to deal with this absolute, imminent threat—this non-specific threat. So, if Monday was too late, it implies that the government acted at the earliest opportunity to deal with this matter. As I stated earlier, I am extremely cynical about that. It is clear that the government knew on Tuesday, and I am assuming that the government actually knew either over the weekend, or on Monday at the latest, and chose not to act until after the Melbourne Cup and the day they introduced the industrial relations reform. That is why it is critical that the government answers this question about when it was first briefed—when it knew that this terrorist threat was there.

speech.para: The second thing I would like to know is what consultation was taken, if this threat was so urgent, in respect of why the terror warning was not upgraded—if this was so urgent that we had to come back and deal with it immediately. The third point I want to raise is in relation to the government’s claim that the advice it has had from its security agents was credible. In relation to that, I note a statement from Prime Minister Howard on 8 November 2001 when he said, ‘Nothing can alter the fact that I have in my possession an ONA report that states baldly that children were thrown in the water.’ An ONA report—a credible report, we were told at the time—which turned out to be totally, utterly false, just like the reasons for going to war in Iraq. We had credible advice from our security agencies on weapons of mass destruction, which was totally wrong. They were wrong on ‘children overboard’; wrong on weapons of mass destruction.

Now we have the same people giving us credible advice, such as would force the Senate to be brought back early to deal with this matter. And this matter is so serious that we parliamentarians cannot be informed about it. The Labor Party and state Labor premiers can be taken into the government’s confidence but not the elected representatives of the Senate—or not all of the elected representatives of the Senate. Indeed, I believe that almost nobody sitting in this chamber now, dealing with it, actually knows. There are half a dozen people who do know, but I cannot see anyone sitting in this room who actually knows—except perhaps the Minister for Defence and the ministers handling the bill for the government.

So I ask specifically: when did the government get its first briefing in relation to this matter? Why would you assume that the security services have credible information when, on committing Australian troops to war and on accusations about children overboard, they were shown to be totally, utterly wrong?

talk.start.para: —We are now getting into repetition of these questions. These are the same questions simply put another way. I have answered these questions. Unless the Greens have anything further, they should move it along. But, more importantly, the Greens should now look to move their amendment, which is still extant and needs to be moved.

speech.para: I have said repeatedly that the briefing was given this week. We received the advice that caused this course of action this week. The Greens have obviously forgotten that we needed to talk to the Leader of the Opposition and the premiers, and to set in place the calling of the Senate—that does not happen in a matter of a few hours. I happen to live in Western Australia, and I know that the Greens, of course, have no regard for Western Australia and do not appreciate the fact that this is a very large continent and people are required to travel across the continent to get to Canberra. I think they should go back to their geography and have another look at the map of Australia if they think you can just call people together in an instant.

But that is the sort of dismissive attitude that we have become accustomed to from the Greens. They have a complete disregard for matters which are practical and logistical, such as briefing the premiers of this country and the Leader of the Opposition, and calling the Senate together and making sure that senators can be available to come here. I was involved in that process, which involved looking at where people were. For my part, I travelled from Perth in Western Australia, which was a good deal further than Senator Milne travelled.

talk.start.para: —Minister Ruddock has just sat down in the House of Representatives, having introduced a massive raft of new antiterrorism legislation—legislation that completely redefines the definition of sedition in this country; legislation that seeks to make it illegal for anybody to suggest that they should support armed resistance in a country like Iraq, where people are opposing a foreign occupying force in their country. Mr Ruddock has just sat down after introducing legislation which brings in random stop and search powers right across this country. That is Mr Beazley’s ‘lock them in the suburbs’ idea and it has just been introduced into the House of Representatives by Mr Ruddock.

speech.para: Another thing in the legislation that has just been introduced into the House of Representatives is control orders. Control orders seek to put Australians in their homes but deny them access to the telephone and use of the internet, and they can hold them in their homes for 12 months. That is house arrest. We have not seen a lot of that in this country, but there are a lot of Australians who used to live in places like Burma and China who have a lot of experience regarding what these house arrest orders do. The Attorney-General, Minister Ruddock, has just sat down in the House of Representatives having introduced into our parliament a piece of legislation that seeks to bring in control orders and house arrest. That will dramatically change the entire system of law enforcement that exists in this country. It will give police extraordinary powers, unlike the ones they have already been given by the government and the opposition to deal with these issues of terrorism.

Minister Ruddock has just sat down having described another provision of that bill, a provision which goes to what he calls preventative detention—that is, being able to take people away and to question them for 14 days without taking them before a court, without them having any trial and without finding them guilty. The government already has that power, and it already does it, but Minister Ruddock has just sat down in the House of Representatives having asked for more power. Not only are we debating this piece of legislation in the Senate today, but Minister Ruddock has just sat down in the House of Representatives having said: ‘That’s not enough. We need more than that. You can’t just introduce 30 new pieces of security legislation. Oh, no. It’s not good enough for ASIO and our police forces to be able to lock people up and question them for seven days without trial, without taking them before the court. Let’s double that—let’s go for 14 days.’ Perhaps we will see legislation like that introduced in the United Kingdom earlier this week, when Tony Blair, the Labour head of the United Kingdom, said: ‘We want to lock them up for 90 days.’ What do you reckon about police being able to lock people up, not take them before a court and not take them for a trial for 90 days?

talk.start.para: —In France it’s three years.

—Senator McGauran is interjecting. Maybe that interjection from the government is a sign of things to come, because Senator McGauran is suggesting that people should be able to be locked up for three years. We already have seven days, Minister Ruddock has just sat down after introducing a bill for 14 days, we have the Labour Party in the United Kingdom saying that it should be 90 days, and we have Senator McGauran over there saying that it should be three years. That is not the sort of country that I want to live in. That is not the kind of Australia that people understand when they think about a welcoming and open country where people are given a fair go. There is no fair go in John Howard’s security regime. There is no fair go before a court. There is no fair go to get a trial. There is no fair go to be convicted of an offence before you get locked up by security services in this country.

speech.para: Senator McGauran is not happy to sit there and say, ‘That’s all right.’ He wants to yell out and suggest that people should be locked up for three years with no fair go. That is not the kind of Australia that people have signed up to be a part of. It might be the sort of Australia that you want, Senator McGauran, but it is certainly not the kind of Australia that the Greens want to be a part of, and it is certainly not the kind of Australia that people who have come from dictatorships and countries where they have experienced house arrest have come to Australia to enjoy. That is why this government—your government—should not be introducing this entirely new security regime that your Attorney-General, Philip Ruddock, has just introduced into the House of Representatives. He has just sat down having said: ‘We want more powers. Those 30 bills we have passed since September 11, 2001—not good enough. We want more powers.’ The Greens say: ‘No way. No, thank you. We won’t be signing onto any new antiterrorism security legislation that seeks to perpetuate the scaring of people in our community.’

As Senator Milne said before, fear is a very strong motivating factor, and our Prime Minister, John Howard, is an extraordinary master of utilising and manipulating that fear. You can do a lot of different things with fear, and this government has chosen to use it to introduce more and more powers for our security services. There are other things that you can do in response to fear. You can smile at someone as you walk down the street. You can talk to your neighbours. You can appreciate the great number of people from all around this world who have come to make this the great country that it is. That should be the government’s response. That is how it could be responding to fear.

When I get into a cab and go to the airport to come here, as I did for an extraordinary sitting of the Senate, I often sit with someone who has come from another country—a country in which they have experienced tyranny and dictatorship—and when I speak with them about the type of legislation we are debating today, and the type of legislation that was introduced into the House of Representatives this afternoon, they look at me in disbelief. They say that they fled the Communist regime in China, the military dictatorship in Burma, the secret police in Turkey or whatever it may have been, and they thought they were coming to a free, open and welcoming country where there was respect for diversity and multiculturalism.’ People still say, ‘I came to Australia because I thought it was multicultural.’

House arrest, random stop and search, preventative detention for 48 hours without being brought before a court, control orders that lock people in their homes for 12 months, sedition clauses that mean you cannot talk about what is going on with people in armed resistance opposing foreign occupying troops in other countries—that is things like East Timor and support for Fretilin that has existed in this country; outlawing that. That is what has just been introduced into the House of Representatives by Minister Ruddock.

We are here today to talk about a piece of security legislation that changes the word ‘the’ to the word ‘a’. A number of questions have been asked of the minister who is responsible for this legislation. But, unfortunately, we have not heard a number of answers. I would like to ask the minister a couple of questions. A question that I want to ask the minister follows on from the comments that were made today by a criminal lawyer who is involved in these security cases who said that the courts are already interpreting the legislation in the way in which the government intended. The minister responded to some comments but he did not respond to all of them, so I wanted to ask the minister if he was able to tell the Senate of any case or instance where the courts have not interpreted the existing Criminal Code and security legislation in the way the government intended. Is the government able to give us any examples? People have been asking for a while, ‘Why is this going on, what is it going to do and how is it going to make any difference?’ Perhaps the minister could give us an example of any court case or any instance in which the courts have interpreted the legislation in a way other than as the government say they intended.

talk.start.para: —The government is not aware of any case which has been decided in such a manner. If Senator Nettle has any case that she can point to, I would certainly have a look at it, but I can tell you that the government is not aware of any decision of any court which interprets this section in a way that would accord with the amendments that we are moving today or in this bill. I think that is pretty clear. I might just ask Senator Nettle, while I am on my feet, whether the Greens intend to proceed with their amendment. There is a Greens amendment which has been circulated. I think that the debate has been going around in circles, so if that amendment is not going to be put then we should look at concluding the debate.

—I want to take a moment to say that I was completely misrepresented by the speaker from the Greens, Senator Nettle, when she claimed that I was seeking a three-year detention in these antiterrorist laws. The truth of the matter is, and I suggest that the Hansard will show it, that I was simply citing the antiterrorist laws as I believe them to be in France, where one Willie Brigitte has been held for some two years without charge. I believe the French law has a maximum three-year detention.

—I am not sure if the minister understood the question that I asked. I thought he said at the beginning, ‘I am not aware of any case,’ and I am also not aware of any case in which the court has interpreted this law, the existing Criminal Code and Anti-Terrorism Act, in any way other than what the government have stated is their intention. The government stated the intention of how they want the legislation interpreted and the minister has done it here in this chamber. In my second reading remarks I said that senior lawyers who have been involved in such criminal trials have said that the law is already being interpreted in the way in which the government intended. My question was, ‘Are you aware of any instance in which the court has not interpreted it in the way in which the government intended?’ The minister said, ‘No, I am not aware of any case,’ but he then went on to say, ‘I am not aware of any case in which it has been interpreted in the way we intended.’ I just wanted to see if I could get that clear. Is the minister saying the courts have been interpreting it the way the government intended, or is the minister saying that the courts have not been interpreting it in the way it is intended?

—To make it abundantly clear, the government is not aware of any decision which has been made by a court that is a decided case which has involved an interpretation of this section which is in accordance with the original intention. That is, Senator Nettle is putting across the proposal that lawyers have said, ‘This bill is not necessary because the courts have been deciding in such a way that we do not need to amend this section.’ I say I believe them to be wrong. The government is not aware of any decision of a court which has interpreted this section in such a way as to avoid any need for an amendment. If these lawyers are commenting on ongoing cases, they should be very careful. I would remind them of the sub judice rule. Certainly, I am not going to engage in comment on cases that are ongoing and nor should they. The only way you can rely on precedent is to look at a case which has been decided by a court, where it is on the record that there has been a decision, and my advice from the Attorney-General’s Department is that it is not aware of such a decision being decided in the manner which has been proposed by the lawyers whom Senator Nettle is relying on.

—Thank you for making that clear, Minister. Are you aware of any case that has been finalised in which this section has been interpreted in a way in which the government did not intend? You have said you are not aware of any case in which it has been interpreted in a way which the government did intend; are you aware of any case in which the court has interpreted it in a way that the government did not intend?

—Let me be very clear: the advice I have is that there has not been a decision of a court which has dealt with this specific issue in relation to the amendment that we are looking at in this bill. That is to say, there is no decision that I am aware of which has decided this one way or another in relation to the interpretation of the section. That is my advice. The government has not claimed that there is any court decision in relation to this which points either way, but we have relied on the advice of the Director of Public Prosecutions on this particular point. Of course, the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Bugg QC, is an eminent lawyer and he heads a very professional team in the DPP and we take his advice seriously.

—Thank you for making it clear that you believe there are no cases that have been decided on these issues and therefore it is the government’s intention to make that clear by moving this amendment. I want to ask you to clarify something and put it on the record. I do not understand any of this to be retrospective, but I think it is worth putting that on the record, because we have been talking about cases that are ongoing. I am not accusing it of being a legal tactic but, if we could just have it on record that it is not, I think that might be helpful.
—To make it absolutely clear: this bill has no retrospective effect.

—Could the minister address another issue, which is around how this clause will be interpreted and the definition of ‘terrorist act’ in the legislation. I am looking at section 100.1 of the Criminal Code Act, in which ‘terrorist act’ is defined, in part (3). It says:

quote.para: Action falls within this subsection if it:
(a) is advocacy, protest, dissent or industrial action; and
(b) is not intended:
(i) to cause serious harm that is physical harm to a person; or
(ii) to cause a person’s death; or
(iii) to endanger the life of a person, other than the person taking the action; or
(iv) to create a serious risk to the health or safety of the public or a section of the public.

speech.para: I want to ask the minister whether or not that would impact on somebody who was attending a training workshop or school being run about non-violent direct action. Can the minister rule out that somebody attending a workshop on non-violent direct action would be prosecuted under these amendments?

talk.start.para: —This amendment does not have any application to section 100.1. Senator Nettle talks about a terrorist act and talks about all the aspects of that, but this does not affect that provision. I think that point should be made at the outset. Senator Nettle has asked me a hypothetical question and one which basically requires the giving of legal advice, which you do not do in a committee stage. However, I can say, as I said in the second reading debate, that only terrorists have need to be concerned about this amendment. If someone is engaged in peaceful protest or action of political expression and it is in accordance with the law, they have nothing to fear. I think that is very clear. With regard to section 100.1, this does not impact on its definition of ‘terrorist act’ at all.
—Unfortunately I did not get to hear all of your answer in relation to that issue, Minister, because I was engaged in a conversation with your colleague.
—It’s a cunning government plan!
—That is not my claim. Could I just ask you to outline that again. I am sorry; I was engaged in discussion with your colleague.

—This amendment has no effect on the definition of ‘terrorist act’ which is in section 100.1. The scenario that Senator Nettle put to me is a hypothetical one, and we do not engage in giving legal advice during the committee stage. But I can say this: if someone is attending a workshop and engaging in some political thought and expression and they are acting within the law, they have nothing to fear from these laws. Only terrorists do. Political expression, as long as it is within the law, is more than acceptable—it is part of our democratic system. If someone is engaged in such activity and it is within the law, then they have nothing to fear at all. Only terrorists do.

—I think that Scott Parkin thought that attending a workshop on non-violent direct action was a part of our democratic system as well. Unfortunately, he is now in Los Angeles and has been handed a bill of over $10,000 for his deportation—for his airfare and for the travel and accommodation in Disneyland of the two members of the Victorian corrections service who travelled with him, which came to $6,000.

speech.para: Scott Parkin also shared your view, Minister, that attending a non-violent direct action workshop in Melbourne was a part of our democracy. But his experience was quite different to that, as he was held in solitary confinement for five days underneath a police headquarters in Melbourne on the direction of the head of the Department of Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs, Mr Andrew Metcalfe.
I will now address the issues dealt with in the amendment which has been circulated in my name and which I now move:

amendment.para: (1) Clause 4, page 2 (after line 19), at the end of the clause, add:
(3) The review required by section 4 of the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002 must review the operation of the amendments made by Schedule 1 of this Act.

(4) The Attorney-General must cause a copy of the report of the review required by subsection (3) to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days after the Attorney-General receives the copy of the report.

speech.para: The amendment goes to the review, as outlined in the legislation, which the minister said a bit about previously. The relevant section says that the Council of Australian Governments agreed on 27 September 2005 that the council would, after five years, review the operation of the amendments made by schedule 1. The second part of that clause in the legislation says—and I note in particular the first word of the clause:

quote.para: (2) If a copy of the report in relation to the review is given to the Attorney-General, the Attorney-General must cause a copy of the report to be laid before each House of Parliament within 15 sitting days after the Attorney-General receives the copy of the report.

speech.para: It does not say ‘when’ the Attorney-General receives a copy of the report of the review into the legislation that he must table it in parliament. It says ‘if’ the Attorney-General receives a copy of the report of the review. We do not have the detail yet; perhaps it is in the bill that has just been introduced into the House of Representatives. I have just been given a fresh copy of that new terrorism legislation and I have not been able to get to the bit that outlines what the review process is that has been agreed to by COAG. If the minister would like to point it out to me I would be more than happy to look at this fresh copy of the new legislation and find out what the review process is. But I have just received that copy so, until somebody tells me where the review is in the new bill, all I know is that chief ministers and premiers agreed to a review in five years time. I do not know the detail of that review.

The review of security legislation which I do know the details of—partly because I was listening to Minister Ruddock when he was just talking about them in the House of Representatives, and he had also announced them on 12 October this year—is the independent committee that has been established to assess the operation and effectiveness of Australia’s existing security laws. The Security Legislation Review Committee, as Minister Ruddock just said in the House of Representatives, will be chaired by the Hon. Simon Sheller QC, a recently retired New South Wales Supreme Court judge. The committee is comprised of former ACT chief police officer John Davies, the Inspector-General of Intelligence and Security, the Privacy Commissioner, the Human Rights Commissioner, the Commonwealth Ombudsman and representatives of the Law Council. As Minister Ruddock said, the review is a statutory requirement of the Security Legislation Amendment (Terrorism) Act 2002. It will look at a raft of security and terrorism legislation, such as laws on suppressing the financing of terrorism, the Criminal Code as it relates to the suppression of terrorist bombings, border security legislation and telecommunications interception legislation. This committee is required to report in six months and its report will be tabled in parliament.

The bill we are debating today will amend some of the terrorism offences contained in the legislation that is being reviewed by that committee. So it seems sensible to me and to the Greens that the committee currently reviewing these offences should also review the amended schedules in the legislation we are debating today. The review would also be useful in resolving competing views about the necessity of the amendments in the bill we are debating today. The Greens’ amendment which I have moved will require the committee to include the provisions of this bill in its current review. I also want to make it clear that the reference to the review by COAG in five years time will remain. So the Greens’ amendment is saying: ‘There is already a group of independent people on a committee who are looking at our security legislation. They should be tasked with reviewing this amendment.’

What is currently in the legislation is that COAG has come up with a way to have a review, but it does not say what that is. Maybe that is in the new bill, and I am happy if it can be pointed out where that COAG review is described. All the legislation currently says is that ‘if’ the COAG review occurs and the Attorney-General is given a copy he will have to table that in parliament. That is not good enough for the Greens. We want to ensure that the COAG review happens but, more than that, we want to ensure that an independent review of this legislation occurs. As it happens, there is one going on at the moment. So it is entirely reasonable for us to say: ‘What about we make sure that this is referred to the existing review of security legislation that is going on and then we will have this aspect of the legislation looked at by the independent committee and we will also be able to allow the COAG review to continue?’ So our amendment does not change the COAG review. It simply says, ‘The guys who are looking at the security legislation now: how about you check out this bit as well?’ That is that the Greens’ amendment is. I commend that amendment to the Senate and I look forward to the support of those people who are interested in a review of security legislation.

talker.name: Evans, Sen Chris
talker.role: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate
talker.name: Senator CHRIS EVANS

talk.start.para: —As much as it pains me to disappoint Senator Nettle, I think her latest contribution highlights her problem—that is, she wants to debate the next bill and deal with provisions that may or may not be in the next bill and things that Mr Ruddock may have said today about the next bill as we consider this bill, the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005. That is her fundamental difficulty. The reality today is that we have an amendment which seeks to deal with the issues of the checks and balances in the broader legislation and the review of the broader legislation.

speech.para: There is no need, I think, to review this particular clause but there obviously is a need to have proper review mechanisms in the broader legislation. This amendment will go through today. Within two weeks or so we will be debating the broader legislation, and the appropriateness of the review and the checks and balances contained in it, analysing the COAG agreement, analysing what Mr Ruddock apparently announced today and making a decision on those issues of checks and balances and a review of the total legislation.

To attempt to put that into this very small amendment bill, which deals with one issue, is putting the cart before the horse. I do not think it is necessary and, as I say, it is a piecemeal approach. The broader issue, which Senator Nettle quite rightly highlights—the question of review and checks and balances—I think would be premature. We are happy to discuss those issues as we have the standard debate over the next month, and I think it is an important issue. The other thing is, if the amendment was successfully carried today, it will probably be after the Reps have adjourned and the effect of successfully carrying the amendment would mean the legislation would not pass until next Monday at the earliest, which defeats the argument about urgency et cetera. So on those bases, the Labor Party will be opposing the amendment.

talk.start.para: —The government really sees no need for this amendment. Senator Nettle has mentioned the Sheller review—Simon Sheller is a distinguished former judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales. That review is able to look into the terrorism offences in the Criminal Code. As well as that, there is the review contained in the amendment. We cannot bind COAG to its report, but I must say COAG has given a public undertaking—I think that is as strong as you can get. But on that basis the government does not see this amendment as necessary.

—Briefly, for the record, I think there have been some valid points made by the last two speakers. Having said that, I do not see any harm in this being supported at this stage. For that reason, the Democrats are not averse to supporting it.

—Can the minister clarify what I thought you said, which was: there are no details in this bill about how the COAG review will occur. I thought you said, ‘We’ll leave that up to COAG, and they can work that out.’ The reason I ask that is that the amendment we are being asked to pass today refers to the COAG agreement about how the review will occur. As I said before, I am happy to have pointed out to me where it is in this next bill, but I thought the minister’s contribution was: it is not there. I am happy to have that pointed out to me as well. Could the minister clarify that?

speech.para: The other issue I would like to ask the minister to clarify is why this amendment was drafted in such a way that it says: if a copy of the report is given to the Attorney-General he has to make it public. I would have thought that if it is the government’s intention to do the review then you would write: when the Attorney-General is given a copy of the report he will make it public. I ask the minister to address that point also.

talk.start.para: —Clause 4 in this bill and clause 4 in the bill in the other place cover this aspect of the review. As I said earlier, we are dealing with the Council of Australian Governments, which has agreed to carry out the review after five years. The reason why it says, ‘If a copy of the report in relation to the review is given to the Attorney-General,’ is that this legislation cannot bind COAG. We are talking about other governments. What I have said is that COAG has given a public undertaking. You have an undertaking from the Council of Australian Governments—a very public one—and I think that is one which the Australian community can take great assurance from. But we cannot legislate in this bill to bind COAG. We are talking about other governments in Australia, and that is why it is there. There is no mystery surrounding it, and I point to the very public undertaking COAG gave on this issue.

—Thank you, Minister, for that explanation. It is great having COAG, isn’t it, because it does not have anywhere near the same sorts of accountability measures as our parliaments do, whether it be environment legislation or a whole raft of other legislation that can be agreed to by COAG. There can be no requirements for the same level of accountability of minutes, information about what is going on at meetings or requirements to ensure that COAG carries out particular things. It makes it all very convenient, and we have seen in a raft of different areas the way this government has sought to move more of the responsibilities out of our parliaments and into meetings of parliaments that cannot be required to have the same sort of accountability. I accept your explanation. It makes sense to me that that would be a forum where you would rather have this issue dealt with.

speech.para: Question negatived.

talk.start.para: —It is not my intention to call a division. I ask that the opposition of the Labor Party and the government be noted.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

motion.para: That this bill be now read a third time.

subdebate.2.para: Debate resumed from 13 October, on motion by Senator Hill:

motion.para: That, upon its introduction in the House of Representatives, the provisions of the Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005 be referred to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report by 8 November 2005.

subdebate.2.para: upon which Senator Bartlett had moved by way of an amendment:

quote.para: Omit “8 November 2005”, substitute “28 November 2005”

talk.start.para: (Senator Lightfoot)—Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 13 October 2005, the Senate should now proceed to a division on the amendment moved by Senator Bartlett to the motion moved by the Minister for Defence, Senator Hill, to refer a bill to the Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee. It has been indicated to me that it may no longer be necessary for the Senate to divide on the amendment, so I intend to put the question again. The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Bartlett be agreed to.

motionnospeech.name: Senator ELLISON
motionnospeech.role: —Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

quote.para: Omit “Anti-Terrorism Bill 2005”, substitute “Anti-Terrorism Bill (No. 2) 2005”.

talk.start.para: —The question now is that Senator Hill’s motion, as amended, be agreed to.

motionnospeech.para: Original question, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Senator Hill to move on the next day of sitting:

item.para: That the Senate—

item.label: (a)
item.para: records its deep regret at the death on 17 October 2005 of Mr William (Evan) Allan, the last Australian World War I veteran to have seen active service in that conflict;

item.label: (b)
item.para: tenders its sympathy to his family in their bereavement; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: expresses its heartfelt thanks on behalf of a grateful nation to all the men and women who answered the call to serve Australia in World War I.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads, upon notice, on 11 April 2005:

item.para: For the financial year 2004-05 to date, on what occasions has the Minister’s special advisor, Mr Graeme Hallett, attended public meetings of Wyong Shire Council and its committees, and on each occasion: (a) was the attendance authorised by the Minister; and (b) can details of the meeting be provided including when the meeting was held, its location, the nature of the meeting and the purpose of Mr Hallett’s attendance.

For the financial year 2004-05 to date, on what occasions has the Minister’s special advisor, Mr Graeme Hallett, attended private meetings at the Wyong Shire Council chambers, and on each occasion: (a) was the attendance authorised by the Minister; and (b) can details of the meeting be provided including when the meeting was held, who attended the meeting, the nature of the meeting and the purpose of Mr Hallett’s attendance.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Local Government, Territories and Roads has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: Minister Lloyd did not request his Special Adviser, Mr Graeme Hallett, attend any public meetings of Wyong Shire Council and its committees. (b) Not applicable.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Minister Lloyd did not request his Special Adviser, Mr Graeme Hallett, attend any private meetings at the Wyong Shire Council chambers. (b) Not applicable.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 28 April 2005:

item.para: For the period 1 July 2004 to 31 March 2005: (a) what was the total cost of Commonwealth expenditure on the Medicare Safety Net for eligible Medicare card holders who qualify for the lower threshold; (b) what was the total cost of Commonwealth expenditure on the Medicare Safety Net for eligible Medicare card holders who qualify for the higher threshold; (c) what was the proportion of total Commonwealth expenditure on the Medicare Safety Net in relation to what was spent on: (i) specialist services, (ii) diagnostic services, (iii) General Practitioner services, (iv) pathology services, and (v) other services; and (d) what was the breakdown, by federal electorate, of Commonwealth expenditure on the Medicare Safety Net.

For each of the financial years 2004-2005, 2005-2006, 2006-2007, and 2007-2008, what was the projected cost of the Medicare Safety Net prior to the announcement by the Prime Minister on 14 April 2005 that the government intends to increase the thresholds.

In each of the three quarters from 1 July 2004 to 31 March 2005, what was the average percentage by which charges exceeded the schedule fee for: (a) specialist services; (b) General Practitioner services; (c) diagnostic services; and (d) pathology services.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: and (b) The Extended Medicare Safety Net commenced on 12 March 2004, and applies to non-hospital patient billed services on a calendar year of service basis. In the date of processing period to 31 December 2004, the Health Insurance Commission (HIC) paid extended safety net benefits of $82,784,850 to patients on the lower threshold and $83,653,595 to patients on the higher threshold.

item.label: (c) (i)
item.para: (ii) (iii) (iv) and (v) Details of Extended Medicare Safety Net benefits by broad type of service group, based on claims processed by the HIC in the period 12 March 2004 to 31 December 2004, are as follows:
EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY NET BENEFITS PAID BY BROAD TYPE OF SERVICE GROUP 2004 (YEAR OF PROCESSING)

item.label: (d)
item.para: The latest published statistics on Extended Medicare Safety Net benefits by federal electoral division (2001 boundaries) have regard to claims processed up to and including 31 July 2004. Details are as follows:
EXTENDED MEDICARE SAFETY NET BENEFITS BY ELECTORATE TO 31 JULY 2004
Note – based on substantiated claims.

The estimated cost of the Extended Medicare Safety Net prior to the announcement by the Prime Minister on 14 April 2005, that the government intended increasing the thresholds, is summarised in the following Table:
* These costs include administered and departmental components.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: , (b), (c) and (d) The percentage by which aggregate fees charged exceeded aggregate Schedule fees by broad type of service group, for non-hospital patient billed services in each quarter from 1 July 2004 to 31 March 2005, are as follows:

quote.para: MEDICARE - NON-HOSPITAL PATIENT BILLED SERVICES PERCENTAGE BY WHICH FEES CHARGED EXCEEDED SCHEDULE FEES SEPTEMBER QUARTER 2004 TO MARCH QUARTER 2005 (QUARTER OF PROCESSING)
Notes to the Table in Answer to Question (1)(d):

These statistics are the latest published statistics on Extended Medicare Safety Net benefits by federal electoral division. The statistics have regard to all claims processed by the HIC up to and including 31 July 2004.
The statistics were compiled from postcode level data (postcode of the head of the household, otherwise postcode of the oldest member of the family) and are based on 2001 electorate boundaries.

Where a postcode overlapped electorate boundaries, statistics were allocated to electorate using a concordance file derived from population census data. This can result in some data being erroneously allocated to an adjoining electorate. Data for people using post office boxes or private mail bags are excluded from electorate reporting as this cannot be appropriately allocated. Data have also been excluded if postcodes were not present on the concordance files.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General and the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 4 May 2005

quote.para: For each of the financial years 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date, can the following information be provided for the department and/or its agencies:

item.para: What were the base and top level salaries of Australian Public Service (APS) level 1 to 6 officers and equivalent staff employed.
What were the base and top level salaries of APS Executive level and Senior Executive Service officers and equivalent staff employed.

Are APS officers eligible for performance or other bonuses; if so: (a to what levels are these bonuses applied; (b) are these applied on an annual basis; (c) what conditions are placed on the qualification of these bonuses; and (d) how many bonuses were paid at each level, and what was their dollar value for the periods specified above.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: How many senior officers have been supplied with motor vehicles; and (b) what has been the cost to date.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: How many senior officers have been supplied with mobile phones; and (b) what has been the cost to date.
How many management retreats or training programs have staff attended.
How many management retreats or training programs have been held off‑site.

In the case of each off-site management retreat or training program: (a) where was the event held; and (b) what was the cost of: (i) accommodation, (ii) food, (iii) alcohol, (iv) transport, and (v) other costs incurred.

How many official domestic trips have been undertaken by staff and what was the cost of this domestic travel, and in each case: (a) what was the destination; (b) what was the purpose of the travel; and (c) what was the cost of the travel, including a breakdown of: (i) accommodation, (ii) food, (iii) alcohol, (iv) transport, and (v) other costs incurred.

How many official overseas trips have been undertaken by staff and what was the cost of this travel, and in each case: (a) what was the destination; (b) what was the purpose of the travel; and (c) what was the cost of the travel, including a breakdown of: (i) accommodation, (ii) food, (iii) alcohol, (iv) transport, and (v) other costs incurred.

(a) What was the total cost of air charters used, and (b) on how many occasions was aircraft chartered, and in each case, what was the name of the charter company that provided the service and the respective costs.

talk.start.para: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: Senator Abetz, as the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service (Mr Andrews) in the Senate, will respond on behalf of all ministers to parts (1), (2) and (3).
The table at Attachment A addresses parts (4) and (5).
Senator Abetz, representing Mr Andrews, will respond on behalf of all ministers to parts (6), (7), (8), (9) and (10).
The table at Attachment B addresses part (11). Those agencies not identified in the table provided a ‘Nil’ response.
Attachment A
Information relating to parts 4 and 5 of the question is contained in the table below.
Costs are rounded to the nearest dollar. ‘Senior officer’ is defined as SES or equivalent.

para.inline: (4) Senior officers supplied with motor vehicles
(5) Senior officers supplied with mobile phones
Mobile phones are for official use only and personal calls are expected to be reimbursed by the user. No figures are available.
ACPR is not part of the APS, and its employees are employed under a certified agreement of the AFP.
Data is not available for 2000-01 and 2001-02.
* No data available for one phone in 2002-03.
For March – April 2005, average cost for mobile phones issued to SES was $63 per officer per month.

Calculations are based on actual costs attributed to customs less cost of personal contributions. Variations in yearly costs can be attributed to several factors including differing numbers of SES, taxation changes associated with the introduction of GST, and the most recent variation mainly due to the new Government lease deal offers being passed onto the Commonwealth.

During the period 2000–01 to 2004–05, customs changed telecommunications suppliers. Due to incompatibilities between the accounting systems of the old and new suppliers, customs is unable to provide this information without a significant diversion of resources. In accordance with customs Chief Executive Instructions, mobile phones are issued to individual officers for official purposes where a demonstrated need exists. The individual AWA of each senior officer determines the extent to which customs meets the costs of use for each mobile phone.
Not applicable as AFP is not part of the APS, and its employees are not employed under the Public Service Act.
Not applicable as AGS is a statutory authority and a government business enterprise. Employees are not employed under the Public Service Act.

Not applicable as AIPM is not part of the APS, and its employees are employed under a certified agreement of the AFP.
Mobile phone expenditure is not separately identified in the agency’s accounts due to its small size. Unable to provide this information without a significant diversion of resources.
Information not publicly provided for reasons of national security.
Tribunal staff provided by the Federal Court.
CRC does not have senior officers equivalent to SES level.

Unable to provide this information without a significant diversion of resources. The following statement of Court policy on the provision and use of mobile phones is provided: The Court issues mobile phones to most senior officers primarily for business use, with only reasonable private use permitted. Where the private use of a Court mobile phone exceeds a reasonable level, senior officers are required to reimburse the Court for this excess use. The court has an effective management control system in place to ensure that this is adhered to on an ongoing basis.
Figures are based on a representative sample of actual motor vehicle costs for vehicles supplied to senior officers in each of the respective years.
The Court does not have SES officers.
Tribunal staff provided by the Federal Court.
