Information for 2000–01 and 2001–02 are contained in financial reports no longer directly accessible. Unable to provide this information without a significant diversion of resources.
Office of Film and Literature Classification

Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions
Office of the Federal Privacy Commissioner

Unable to provide this information without a significant diversion of resources. OPC changed to a new financial management information system two years ago and data from previous years can now only be accessed manually by going through every invoice relating to phone expenses.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry: Overseas Travel

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, upon notice, on 4 May 2005:

item.para: In relation to all overseas travel where expenses were met by the Minister’s portfolios, for each of the financial years 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date what was the total cost of travel and related expenses in relation to: (a) the Minister; (b) the Minister’s family; and (c) the Minister’s staff.

In relation to all air charters engaged and paid for by the Minister and/or the Minister’s office and/or the department and its agencies, for each of the financial years 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date: (a) on how many occasions did the Minister or his/her office or department and/or agency charter aircraft, and in each case, what was the name of the charter company that provided the service and the related respective costs; and (b) what was the total cost.

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for Fisheries, Forestry and Conservation
talker.name: Senator Ian Macdonald

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: and (c)

para.inline: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

item.para: Overseas travel costs incurred by the Minister and met by the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry are limited to items such as additional security costs, interpreters, portfolio related hospitality, mobile phones call costs and the provision of business cards.

The “overseas” nature of these costs is not listed separately in departmental records relating to ministerial expenses. Extensive analysis of departmental records would be required to identify these costs and I am not prepared to authorise the resources to undertake this task.
Land and Water Australia has advised that the requested information is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the resources to undertake this task.
All other portfolio agencies have advised that no other expenses have been paid.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Nil
This part of the question has been interpreted as relating to overseas charter travel only.

para.inline: Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry

item.para: The “overseas” nature of charter travel is not listed separately in departmental records relating to ministerial expenses. It is not possible to identify costs that specifically relate to overseas travel without undertaking extensive analysis of Departmental records and I am not prepared to authorise the resources to undertake this task.

Land and Water Australia and the Grape and Wine Research and Development Corporation have advised that the requested information is not readily available and I am not prepared to authorise the resources to undertake this task.
All other portfolio agencies have advised that no aircraft have been chartered overseas.

subdebateinfo.title: Minister for Justice and Customs: Overseas Travel

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 4 May 2005

quote.para: For each financial year since 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date:

item.label: (1) (a)
item.para: What overseas travel was undertaken by the Minister; (b) what was the purpose of the Minister’s visit; (c) when did the Minister depart Australia; (d) who travelled with the Minister; and (e) when did the Minister return to Australia.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Who did the Minister meet during the visit; and (b) what were the times and dates of each meeting.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: On how many of these trips was the Minister accompanied by a business delegation; and (b) can details be provided of any delegation accompanying the Minister.
Who met the cost of travel and other expenses associated with the trip.

What total travel and associated expenses, if any, were met by the department in relation to: (a) the Minister; (b) the Minister’s family; (c) the Minister’s staff; and (d) departmental and/or agency staff.

What were the costs per expenditure item for: (a) the Minister; (b) the Minister’s family; and (c) the Minister’s staff, including but not necessarily limited to: (i) fares, (ii) allowances, (iii) accommodation, (iv) hospitality, (v) insurance, and (vi) other costs.

What were the costs per expenditure item for each departmental and/or agency officer, including but not necessarily limited to: (a) fares; (b) allowances; (c) accommodation; (d) hospitality; (e) insurance; and (f) other costs.

item.label: (8) (a)
item.para: What was the total cost of air charters used by the Minister or his/her office or department; and (b) how many occasions did the Minister or his/her office or department and/or agency charter aircraft, and in each case, what was the name of the charter company that provided the service and the respective costs.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State and other ministers, upon notice, on 4 May 2005:

item.para: For each of the financial years from 2000-01 to 2004-05 to date, what sum has the department and/or its agencies spent on consultants.

In relation to each consultancy: (a) what was the name of the consultant employed; (b) what was the cost; (c) what was the purpose; (d) what was the period during which the consultant was engaged; (e) what role did the Minister and/or his/her office have in the engagement of the consultant; and (f) was the consultancy subject to a tender process; if not, why not; if so, was it an open tender or a select tender.

talk.start.para: —I am providing the following answer on behalf of all ministers to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: to (2) Australian Government policy requires agencies that are subject to the Financial Management and Accountability Act 1997 (FMA Act) to report all Commonwealth contracts and agency agreements, including standing offers, with an estimated liability (including GST where applicable) of $10,000 or more (prior to 1 January 2005, this threshold was $2,000 or more) in the Gazette Publishing System (GaPS - now called AusTender), within six weeks of entering into the arrangement. The information recorded in AusTender includes a short description of each contract, the provider of the goods or services, the value of the contract and the selection process. Details of all consultancies with a contract value of $10,000 or more are therefore already publicly available, albeit not in a form that distinguishes consultancies from non-consultancy contracts. Further, the agencies’ annual reports provide information about the number of consultancy contracts let in the financial year to which each report relates, and the total value of payments made to consultants each year, regardless of when the consultancy contract was let. Annual reports also list each consultancy contract let during the year with a value of $10,000 or more, and provide details of the consultant’s identity, the purpose of the consultancy, the contract price and method of selection.

The preparation of answers to these questions would involve a significant diversion of resources and elicit information already on the public record. Agencies do not consider that the additional work can be justified, however, they are ready, of course, to provide further information about any particular contract to which they are a party.

talk.start.para: asked the Special Minister of State, upon notice, on 6 May 2005:

quote.para: For each of the financial years 2000-01, 2001-02, 2002-03, 2003-04 and 2004-05 to date, can details be provided of all privately or commercially sponsored travel, including cost and sponsor for: (a) the Minister; (b) the Minister’s family; (c) the Minister’s personal staff; and (d) officers of the Minister’s department.

talk.start.para: —I am providing the following answers to parts (a) – (b) on behalf of all ministers to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: (a) – (b) Details of sponsored travel by ministers and their families are already on the register of members’ interests.
(c) In relation to any sponsored travel by personal staff of Ministers as part of the Australian Political Exchange Council (APEC) the following answer is provided on behalf of all Ministers.
APEC participates in an annual exchange programme with its American counterpart, the American Council of Young Political Leaders (ACYPL).
ACYPL funding is derived from Corporations, foundations, individuals, and an annual grant from the Bureau of Educational and Cultural Affairs of the United States of America (US) Department of State.

Since 2000, there have been three outgoing delegations from Australia to the US where Ministerial staff have been participants. All in-country expenses within the US for incoming APEC delegations are met by ACYPL, and details of these funding arrangements are not known to the Department of Finance and Administration (Finance).
Dates of the travel to the US are as follows:

entry.para: 6 July to 19 July 2002 – Three personal staff members.
17 July to 30 July 2004 – One personal staff member.
2 April to 15 April 2005 – Three personal staff members.

quote.para: APEC also participates in an annual exchange programme with its Japanese counterpart the Japan Center for International Exchange (JCIE).
JCIE funding is primarily sustained by funds provided by the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs. However, financial support is also provided by private foundations and corporations.

Since 2000, there has been one outgoing delegation from Australia to Japan where a Ministerial staff member has been a participant. All International travel and in-country expenses within Japan for incoming APEC delegations are met by JCIE, and details of these funding arrangements are not known to Finance.
There was no sponsored travel by personal staff of my Office.
(d) Finance also provides the Secretariat to APEC.

Since 2000, there have been four outgoing delegations from Australia to the US where one departmental staff member from the Council Secretariat accompanied the delegation. All in-country expenses within the US for incoming APEC delegations are met by ACYPL, and details of these funding arrangements are not known to Finance.
Dates of the travel to the US were as follows:

Since 2000, there have been five outgoing delegations from Australia to Japan where one departmental staff member from the Council Secretariat accompanied the delegation. All International travel and in-country expenses within Japan for incoming APEC delegations are met by JCIE, and details of these funding arrangements are not known to Finance.
Dates of the travel to Japan were as follows:
There was no other sponsored travel by Finance staff.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

quote.para: No.

Under conventions accepted by successive Governments, departments have not been required to disclose the nature of their advice to Ministers. The material sought by the Committee will effectively result in disclosure of advice given to Ministers and it is not in the public interest to do so as this advice may contain information of a confidential or sensitive nature.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Ageing, upon notice, on 11 July 2005:

item.para: What is the department’s role in negotiating the sale of residential aged care places and facilities between approved providers.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: What mechanisms are in place to ensure that residents, staff and community are consulted about the sale of residential aged care places and facilities between approved providers; and (b) can information be provided to describe the nature of these consultation mechanisms.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: What mechanisms exist to enable residents, staff and community to provide feedback to the department about the sale of residential aged care places and facilities between approved providers; (b) how does the department handle any feedback of this nature; and (c) what part does this feedback play in the department’s decisions regarding these sales.
Does the department investigate and approve the sales of aged care places and facilities.

Can a description be provided of the nature of the approval process, for example, what area of the department considers the sales, who in the department signs off on sales. Is Ministerial sign-off required etc.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: The department has no role in the negotiation of sales between approved providers, however a sale of places requires them to be transferred, and any transfer of operational places cannot occur without the Secretary’s approval.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: and (b) The Aged Care Act 1997 does not require consultation about commercial sales between approved providers. In relation to the transfer of places, the Aged Care Act 1997 requires the Secretary to consider any concerns about the transfer expressed by affected care recipients.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Any member of the public can contact the department with feedback regarding the provision of aged care, including transfers. This can occur through the relevant state or territory office, or through the central office of the department. The Aged Care Complaints Resolution Scheme can also be used to provide feedback. (b) The department considers any feedback and may respond, if appropriate, directly to the person providing the feedback. (c) The department is required under the Aged Care Act 1997 to consider the impact on the current and future care recipients of any potential transfer of places.
Yes, to the extent provided for in Section 16 of the Aged Care Act 1997.

Places cannot be transferred without the Secretary’s approval. Consideration of all applications for transfers take into account the factors contained in section 16-4 of the Aged Care Act 1997 and section 4.63 of the Allocation Principles 1997.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 3 August 2005:

item.para: Would the banning of Australian investors from obtaining majority ownership in Chinese steel mills be accepted in an Australia-China free trade agreement; if so, would Australia reciprocate.
Does a free trade agreement entail restrictions on ownership or investment; if so, to what degree.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: At this stage, it is not possible to answer a question about the outcome of free trade agreement negotiations between Australia and China that are only just underway and are expected to be lengthy and complex.

I am advised that, generally speaking, free trade agreements may or may not bind or liberalise existing foreign ownership restrictions. Whether these issues are included and how they are addressed in a final FTA is a matter for negotiations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 3 August 2005:

item.para: Can information be provided on directives, guidelines or other instructions, issued or developed by the department or the wider Australian Defence Organisation (ADO), regarding the procurement and contracting of transport services by the Commonwealth for either the department or wider ADO, including the Australian Defence Force.

Can information be provided on: (a) when contracts were agreed to; (b) the entity with which the Commonwealth has contracted; and (c) the total costs of the contracts for the 2003-2004 financial year.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable senator’s question is as follows:

item.para: The document containing policy and guidelines for contracting in Defence is the Defence Procurement Policy Manual. This manual accords with the Commonwealth Procurement Guidelines. Guidance and interpretation of this manual is provided by the General Counsel Division within the Defence Materiel Organisation.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: , (b) and (c) The four main organisations in Defence that contract for transport services are Joint Logistics Command, Corporate Services and Infrastructure Group, 1st Joint Movement Group (which is part of Vice Chief of the Defence Force Group) and the Defence Materiel Organisation. The detail of transport contracts in 2003-04 for each of these organisations is shown in the tables following.

quote.para: 67 commercial companies were engaged by Joint Logistics Command for provision of direct transport services for Joint Logistics Command in 2003-04. The list below shows significant contracts; that is, those greater than $100,000 per annum.

entry.para: Australian Defence Force Explosive Ordnance Services contract (estimate).
Metro distribution services and priority airfreight.
Cost of transport services as part of the Defence Integrated Distribution System contract.
Metro distribution services and priority airfreight.
Overseas freight originally with QAFCO (which later became VIP Airfreight) and then merged with Wilson Logistics. No formal contract.

quote.para: Corporate Services and Infrastructure Group is organised into 12 regions within Australia. All regions, with the exception of Tasmania, contract for most of their domestic transport requirements under Garrison Support Services contracts.

Noting that specific requirements for domestic transport tasks can vary between regions, costs associated with domestic transport requirements under the Garrison Support Services contracts generally represent about five per cent of the total annual cost of contracts in each region.

The contracts for short-term vehicle hire (Delta Europcar and Hertz) and for the Executive Vehicle Scheme (Leaseplan) are also managed by Corporate Services and Infrastructure Group on behalf of the whole Defence organisation.

Delta Europcar was contracted to provide short-term vehicle hire from 30 June 1998 to 9 March 2004. Hertz was contracted to provide short-term vehicle hire from 10 March 2004 and is still under contract to Defence for these services.

Prior to 2004-05, Defence did not maintain centralised records for the provision of vehicles by LeasePlan through the Executive Vehicle Scheme. Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources that would be required to provide accurate data concerning SES vehicles and associated costs prior to 2004-05.
The table below shows the total cost of strategic lift contracts for 2003-04.
Defence is not able to devote the considerable time and resources required to provide a response regarding the timing of contracts and the names of those contracted.

Defence Materiel Organisation manages the fleet of commercial vehicles for the Defence organisation. The bulk of the cost is for the provision of fleet management services from LeasePlan Australia and purchase of commercial vehicles for Defence. The procurement action was against standing offers with manufacturers that were established by Defence, but purchased through LeasePlan.

para.inline: Cost of transport services for FY 2003-04

Purchase of 1,466 commercial vehicles against standing offers with vehicle manufacturers ($39.93m); provision of fleet management services for the Defence commercial fleet ($1.37m) and vehicle maintenance ($4.06m)
Progress payments for purchase of seven touring coaches
Progress payments for purchase of 140 medium trucks
Modification of Toyota Landcruiser as a trauma ambulance

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 2005:

quote.para: With reference to general aviation matters in North Queensland:

item.para: Can a list be provided of airlines operating in North Queensland that complied with the Aviation Transport Security Act 2004 as at 10 March 2005, the date on which new security provisions came into effect.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Can the list specify which airlines have not complied, in particular in relation to the purchase and use of wheel clamps, control locks or padlocks connected to permanent tie-down points; and (b) which of those airlines hold Commonwealth contracts.
Can details be provided of the actions the Minister and the department took to ensure compliance with the Act in this respect by 10 March 2005.

Can details be provided of the security arrangements required for North Queensland airport buildings occupied by secondary airlines, in particular, in relation to alarm systems, and what action the Minister and the department have taken to ensure that security measures are adequate and comply with the Act.

Can details be provided of the checks carried out on individual airlines in North Queensland to see that the building security and airport perimeter provisions of this Act were complied with by the due date.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: Yes. All airlines operating a prescribed air service complied with the Aviation Transport Security Act 2004 on 10 March 2005, a list of these airlines is available on the departmental website at:
http://www.dotars.gov.au/transsec/aviation/prescribed_aircraft_operators.aspx.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The list identified on the departmental website identifies all compliant prescribed air services. The Aviation Transport Security Act 2004 and its regulations also require operators of all powered aircraft to take reasonable measures to prevent their aircraft being flown by an unauthorised person. The reasonable measures have been identified by operators according to their local risk context. Audits of this requirement have begun in all states and territories. My department is liaising with non-compliant general aviation operators to inspect that a device has been fitted.

item.label: (b)
item.para: It is not a security requirement for operators to provide this information in their transport security programs. My portfolio has contracts with a number of airlines in Queensland for the provision of services under the Remote Air Services Subsidy scheme. Each of these requiring a transport security program is compliant.

All airlines operating a prescribed air service submitted a transport security program prior to 10 March 2005. As all were approved by the delegate on that date, no follow-up action was required. Prior to the submission of transport security programs, departmental staff ran 32 workshops for airlines and airports entering the aviation security regime and provided many with one-on-one assistance to guide them in their risk assessment and security planning processes.

Transport security programs cover all security aspects of an airport. Airport security committees (which include tenants, airline representatives and local police) play an integral role in maintenance of the measures specified in the transport security program, including ensuring that security measures are commensurate with the local risk assessment.

Audits (ie. ‘checks’) of airports were not carried out before the due date as the legislation did not require compliance before the due date. On 10 March 2005, all operators complied with the requirement to hold a transport security program. Since 10 March 2005, there have been 21 compliance visits to Queensland regional airports and airlines.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources, upon notice, on 10 August 2005:

quote.para: With reference to inbound tourism:

item.para: Has the Government received any representations from the inbound tourist industry, the Transport Workers’ Union or other bodies regarding:

item.label: (a)
item.para: a breach of visa conditions by persons from overseas who are working as guides in the Australian inbound tourist industry;

item.label: (b)
item.para: the exploitation of such guides through their being paid below award wages and being on sub-standard Australian Workplace Agreements; and

item.label: (c)
item.para: the abuse of driver safety regulations with respect to hours of driving.
Has the Government implemented any measures to prevent such abuses.
Is regulation of the use of tour guides and drivers from overseas within the terms of reference of the Tourism Accreditation Working Group.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Tourism and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.label: (a)
item.para: The Department of Immigration, Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs (DIMIA) has not received representations on this matter and has no evidence to suggest that this is a significant issue in the tourism industry.
The Department of Industry, Tourism and Resources (DITR) has received anecdotal advice from tourism industry members that such practices occur.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Department of Employment and Workplace Relations (DEWR) has not received any representations on this matter.
DITR has received anecdotal advice from tourism industry members that such practices occur.

item.label: (c)
item.para: In reference to inbound tourism, the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) is unaware of any abuse of driver safety regulations with respect to hours of driving.
DITR has not received any representations on this matter.
Yes.

The objective of the compliance function of the Office of Workplace Services and the Office of the Employment Advocate are to ensure that the provisions of awards, agreements and the Workplace Relations Act 1996 are observed. This is achieved by helping employers and employees understand, comply with, and as necessary, enforce, their rights, obligations and choices under relevant instruments.
The State and Territory governments have legislative and operational responsibility for driver safety regulations.
DIMIA Compliance staff conduct routine checks across all industries, including the tourism industry, in response to information received about possible non-compliance with visa requirements.
A broad range of actions has been implemented to support regulatory compliance in the inbound tourism sector:

The Inbound Tourism Compliance Taskforce was established in early 2004. The Taskforce brings together Queensland, New South Wales, Victorian and Australian Government tourism and enforcement agencies that have an interest in the activities of some businesses that, in addition to providing a low-quality experience for tourists, may also be in contravention of Commonwealth or State legislation.

A suite of reforms to protect the integrity of the China Approved Destination Status (ADS) scheme and eliminate unethical and illegal practices has recently been implemented. These reforms strengthen the governance and administrative arrangements for the ADS scheme.

The Australian Government provided $96,000 to the Australian Tourism Export Council (ATEC) to assist in the development of a voluntary industry Export Code of Conduct specifically aimed at raising quality in the inbound sector. The Export Code of Conduct is yet to be implemented.

The Australian Government supports the development of a voluntary, industry-led accreditation system, and is funding the development of a Tourism Business and Accreditation Portal to help industry achieve this goal. The Portal will assist tourism businesses in accessing accreditation products and business and management improvement tools.

The Australian Government has provided Guiding Organisations Australia with $100,000 funding to develop and implement a Guide Accreditation Framework. In consultation with stakeholders GOA will produce a set of standards accepted across the industry as appropriate for given guiding roles.

A national ‘Shopping Around in Australia’ brochure (English, Chinese, Japanese and Korean versions) was produced in 2003. This brochure aims to improve consumer awareness of the type of business practices acceptable in Australia. The brochure details complaints mechanisms in the form of a hotline number (1300 55 2263), interpreter service (131 450) and complaint website (www.industry.gov.au/touristcomplaints).
No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 16 August 2005:

item.para: Which new oral contraceptives have been listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) since 1996; if none are listed: (a) why is this the case; and (b) can details be provided of the applications that have been made to list new oral contraceptives on the PBS in that time and the reason why they were not listed.

How many and which lowest dose (20 microgram) oral contraceptives, are currently listed on the PBS; if none have been listed: (a) why is this the case; and (b) can an explanation be provided for why the oral contraceptives Diane 35 Ed (Brenda, Celeste, Juliette, and Estelle), Femoden Ed, Minulet, Trioden Ed, TR-Minulet, Marvelon 28, Microgynon 20 Ed, Loette and Yasmin are not listed on the PBS.
Which low progesterone oral contraceptives are currently listed on the PBS.
For each of the oral contraceptives listed on the PBS, how many doses were funded, by year, from 1996 to date.
Is it the case that Postinor is not listed on the PBS; if so, can details be provided of the reason that it is not listed.
What research has been conducted into patient preferences and reproductive health outcomes for: (a) oral contraceptives on the PBS; and (b) those that are not listed.
What research has been conducted to determine the rate of unwanted pregnancies that arise due to inability to afford oral contraception.

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: No new types of oral contraceptives have been listed on the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) since 1996.

item.label: (a)
item.para: In general terms, if an oral contraceptive is not listed it is because the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee (PBAC) has either not received an application from the sponsor or the PBAC has not been provided with adequate evidence to support a recommendation for the listing.

item.label: (b)
item.para: Applications to the PBAC are considered commercial-in-confidence by the sponsors. PBAC recommendations have only been publicly available from December 1999 (for positive recommendations) and from June 2003 (for decisions not to recommend and deferrals). Information about applications on pricing matters and those subsequently withdrawn by the sponsor are not released publicly.

At its December 1998 meeting, the PBAC recommended that Diane-35 ED®, Femoden ED®, Trioden ED® and Microgynon 20® be made available as pharmaceutical benefits. However, the implementation of a recommendation for listing is dependent, in part, upon a mutually acceptable price being negotiated between the manufacturer and the government. To date, no pricing agreement has been reached and subsequently the products have not been made available as pharmaceutical benefits.

In March 2004, these recommendations were reviewed again by PBAC and consistent with an agreement with the pharmaceutical industry regarding recommendations more than five years old and not implemented, the PBAC agreed to rescind the recommendations for listing.
No low does (20 microgram) oral contraceptives are currently listed on the PBS.

item.label: (a)
item.para: and (b) No applications for the listing of Minulet, TR-Minulet, Marvelon 28, Loette and Yasmin have been received since June 2003, when PBAC recommendations and decisions not to recommend have been publicly available. With respect to applications prior to that date please refer to 1(b) above.
There are no low progesterone oral contraceptives listed on the PBS.
Refer to Attachment A.
Postinor® is not listed on the PBS. No application for PBS listing has been received from the sponsor to date.

item.label: (6) (a)
item.para: and (b) and (7) The National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) is the government’s main health and medical research funding body.
The NHMRC accepts applications, on an annual basis, to undertake research.

The NHMRC provided over $9.6 million in research funding related to oral contraception over the period 2001 to 2005. None of this funding is specifically related to patient preferences and reproductive health outcomes for oral contraceptives whether listed on the PBS or not (question 6), or for research determining the rate of unwanted pregnancies that arise due to inability to afford oral contraception (question 7).

quote.para: Attachment A

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Ageing, upon notice, on 16 August 2005:

item.para: When conducted in day procedure centres, why can a Medicare rebate not be claimed for both a dilation and curettage (D&C) (item number 35640) and the insertion of an inter-uterine contraceptive device (IUD) (item number 35503) when the attending doctor determines that a D&C is necessary prior to insertion of the IUD.

Can information be provided on the reason for the difference in the Medicare rebate for a D&C of $85.90 when performed by a general practitioner in a day procedure centre and $116.50 when performed by a specialist.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Can data be provided on the level of the Medicare rebate over the past decade on item number 35640; and (b) how does this compare with average Medicare rebate increases over the same period.

item.label: (4) (a)
item.para: Can information be provided on the reason for the change in Medicare rebates for terminations of pregnancies post-12 weeks gestation performed in day procedure centres whereby the day one procedure lamtent (item no. 35500) and the day two procedure (item no. 35643) were combined as item no. 16525; and (b) why has this now resulted in no rebate being available for anaesthetist procedures (item nos 17603, 20940 and 23021) used in the day one procedure in termination of pregnancies post-12 week gestation.

Can information be provided on the reason ultrasounds at: (a) less than 12 weeks gestation (item no. 55703) and ultrasounds at 12 to 16 weeks (item no. 55705) have separate item numbers when the rebate is the same ($29.75); and (b) 17 to 22 weeks gestation (item no. 55709) and ultrasounds at 22 plus gestation weeks (item no. 55723) have separate item numbers when the rebate is the same ($32.30).

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
talker.role: Minister for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Women’s Issues
talker.name: Senator Patterson

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Health and Ageing has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: Before items are included in the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) negotiations take place with the relevant professional group to ensure that they reflect proper clinical practice and that any restrictions on the items are appropriate. The professional opinion at the time item 35500 was introduced into the MBS was that it should not be undertaken in association with any other item in Group T8 of the MBS. On that basis, the item has been restricted so that a Medicare rebate cannot be claimed if another item in Group T8 is billed on the same patient on the same day.
Historically, a range of items in the MBS have different rebate levels when performed by a specialist or general practitioner, related to differences in training and opportunity costs.

item.label: (a)
item.para: The following table lists the Medicare rebate for item 35640 for the period 1995-2004:

item.label: (b)
item.para: The average increase in rebates for Item 35640 over the past decade was 1.6% per annum. The average increase in Medicare rebates over the past decade was also 1.6% per annum.

item.label: (a)
item.para: There has been no change in the Medicare rebates for terminations of pregnancies post 12 weeks. Item 35500 is for a gynaecological examination under anaesthesia. It was never intended that this item would be used for the insertion of a laminaria stent. Items 35643 and 16525 cover all aspects of the procedure. Accordingly, item 16525 would include the insertion of a laminaria stent if it was used.

item.label: (b)
item.para: The department has been advised of the situation where an anaesthetic service is not payable in conjunction with the laminaria stent component of the procedure and is consulting with the Health Insurance Commission on this issue.

item.label: (5) (a)
item.para: and (b) The obstetric ultrasound items were developed in conjunction with the medical profession to reflect good clinical practice and to assist in appropriate utilisation of ultrasound. The items were developed to mirror the model of best practice (including the most appropriate timing of ultrasound examinations) developed under the auspices of the AMA by The Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, The Royal Australian College of Radiologists, and The Australian Society for Ultrasound in Medicine as outlined in the Consensus Statement on the Best Use of Diagnostic Ultrasound in Obstetric Practice.
The fees for items are structured to reflect the varying levels of complexity and time taken to perform the obstetric ultrasound.

The current structure of items enables the Government, in consultation with the medical profession, to help ensure that services are provided in accordance with appropriate standards of clinical practice.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 18 August 2005:

quote.para: With reference to the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme (PBS) and the Australia-United States of America (US) Free Trade Agreement:

item.para: Did the Prime Minister discuss changes to the PBS with US officials during his recent visit to the US; if so, what changes were discussed.
Has the Prime Minister agreed to any changes to the PBS.

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: During the visit to Washington, I discussed a number of AUSFTA implementation issues including the convening of working groups such as the Medicines Working Group.
No.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 19 August 2005:

item.para: For the past 5 years, can the Minister provide the following details for all foreign flagged ships that have operated on the Australian coastline under single and/or continuous voyage permits: (a) the name of the ship; (b) the date(s) that the ship operated on the Australian coastline; (c) the cargo carried; (d) the country of origin of the ship; (e) details of the nationality of the crews of each ship; and (f) the type of permit under which each ship operated.

item.label: (2) (a)
item.para: Which of these ships carried ammonium nitrate; (b) when; and (c) between which ports was this cargo carried.

item.label: (3) (a)
item.para: Which of these ships carried other high consequence dangerous goods; (b) when; (c) what were these cargoes; and (d) between which ports were they carried.

talker.name: Campbell, Sen Ian
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage
talker.name: Senator Ian Campbell

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Transport and Regional Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator’s question:

item.para: In response to the senator’s question: (1) (a), (b), (c), (d) and (f) can be found at attachment A (available from the Senate Table Office). Australian Customs Service was consulted in regards to (1) (e) and has advised that they would not have the resources available to undertake the amount of work the nationality searches for the previous five years would entail.
In response to the senator’s question: (2) (a), (b) and c can be found at attachment B (available from the Senate Table Office).

In response to the senator’s question: There are over 1000 high consequence dangerous goods (HCDGs). I am not prepared to commit the resources that would be required to cross match against permit records which may not identify individual commodities so as to allow useful matching with the list of 1000 HCDGs.
